books.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:1
verses.text: The Stromata, or Miscellanies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:2
verses.text: Book 7   Chapter I.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:3
verses.text: —The Gnostic a True Worshipper of God, and Unjustly Calumniated by Unbelievers as an Atheist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:4
verses.text: It is now time to show the Greeks that the Gnostic alone is truly pious; so that the philosophers, learning of what description the true Christian is, may condemn their own stupidity in rashly and inconsiderately persecuting the Christian name, and without reason calling those impious who know the true God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:5
verses.text: And clearer arguments must be employed, I reckon, with the philosophers, so that they may be able, from the exercise they have already had through their own training, to understand, although they have not yet shown themselves worthy to partake of the power of believing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:6
verses.text: The prophetic sayings we shall not at present advert to, as we are to avail ourselves of the Scriptures subsequently at the proper places.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:7
verses.text: But we shall point out summarily the points indicated by them, in our delineation of Christianity, so that by taking the Scriptures at once (especially as they do not yet comprehend their utterances), we may not interrupt the continuity of the discourse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:8
verses.text: But after pointing out the things indicated, proofs shall be shown in abundance to those who have believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:9
verses.text: But if the assertions made by us appear to certain of the multitude to be different from the Scriptures of the Lord, let it be known that it is from that source that they have breath and life; and taking their rise from them, they profess to adduce the sense only, not the words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:10
verses.text: For further treatment, not being seasonable, will rightly appear superfluous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:11
verses.text: Thus, not to look at what is urgent would be excessively indolent and defective; and "blessed, in truth, are they who, investigating the testimonies of the Lord, shall seek Him with their whole heart".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:12
verses.text: And the law and the prophets witness of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:13
verses.text: It is, then, our purpose to prove that the Gnostic alone is holy and pious, and worships the true God in a manner worthy of Him; and that worship meet for God is followed by loving and being loved by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:14
verses.text: He accordingly judges all excellence to be honourable according to its worth; and judges that among the objects perceived by our senses, we are to esteem rulers, and parents, and every one advanced in years; and among subjects of instruction, the most ancient philosophy and primeval prophecy; and among intellectual ideas, what is oldest in origin, the timeless and unoriginated First Principle, and Beginning of existences—the Son—from whom we are to learn the remoter Cause, the Father, of the universe, the most ancient and the most beneficent of all; not capable of expression by the voice, but to be reverenced with reverence, and silence, and holy wonder, and supremely venerated; declared by the Lord, as far as those who learned were capable of comprehending, and understood by those chosen by the Lord to acknowledge; "whose senses," says the apostle, "were exercised".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:15
verses.text: The service of God, then, in the case of the Gnostic, is his soul's continual study and occupation, bestowed on the Deity in ceaseless love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:16
verses.text: For of the service bestowed on men, one kind is that whose aim is improvement, the other ministerial.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:17
verses.text: The improvement of the body is the object of the medical art, of the soul of philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:18
verses.text: Ministerial service is rendered to parents by children, to rulers by subjects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:19
verses.text: Similarly, also, in the Church, the elders attend to the department which has improvement for its object; and the deacons to the ministerial.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:20
verses.text: In both these ministries the angels serve God, in the management of earthly affairs; and the Gnostic himself ministers to God, and  exhibits to men the scheme of improvement, in the way in which he has been appointed to discipline men for their amendment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:21
verses.text: For he is alone pious that serves God rightly and unblameably in human affairs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:22
verses.text: For as that treatment of plants is best through which their fruits are produced and gathered in, through knowledge and skill in husbandry, affording men the benefit accruing from them; so the piety of the Gnostic, taking to itself the fruits of the men who by his means have believed, when not a few attain to knowledge and are saved by it, achieves by his skill the best harvest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:23
verses.text: And as Godliness (θεοπρέπεια) is the habit which preserves what is becoming to God, the godly man is the only lover of God, and such will he be who knows what is becoming, both in respect of knowledge and of the life which must be lived by him, who is destined to be divine (θεῷ), and is already being assimilated to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:24
verses.text: So then he is in the first place a lover of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:25
verses.text: For as he who honours his father is a lover of his father, so he who honours God is a lover of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:26
verses.text: Thus also it appears to me that there are three effects of gnostic power: the knowledge of things; second, the performance of whatever the Word suggests; and the third, the capability of delivering, in a way suitable to God, the secrets veiled in the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:27
verses.text: He, then, who is persuaded that God is omnipotent, and has learned the divine mysteries from His only-begotten Son, how can he be an atheist (ἄθπεος)? Foa he is an atheist who thinks that God does not exist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 1:28
verses.text: And he is superstitious who dreads the demons; who deifies all things, both wood and stone; and reduces to bondage spirit, and man who possesses the life of reason.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2—The Son the Ruler and Saviour of All.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:2
verses.text: To know God is, then, the first step of faith; then, through confidence in the teaching of the Saviour, to consider the doing of wrong in any way as not suitable to the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:3
verses.text: So the best thing on earth is the most pious man; and the best thing in heaven, the nearer in place and purer, is an angel, the partaker of the eternal and blessed life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:4
verses.text: But the nature of the Son, which is nearest to Him who is alone the Almighty One, is the most perfect, and most holy, and most potent, and most princely, and most kingly, and most beneficent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:5
verses.text: This is the highest excellence, which orders all things in accordance with the Father's will, and holds the helm of the universe in the best way, with unwearied and tireless power, working all things in which it operates, keeping in view its hidden designs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:6
verses.text: For from His own point of view the Son of God is never displaced; not being divided, not severed, not passing from place to place; being always everywhere, and being contained nowhere; complete mind, the complete paternal light; all eyes, seeing all things, hearing all things, knowing all things, by His power scrutinizing the powers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:7
verses.text: To Him is placed in subjection all the host of angels and gods; He, the paternal Word, exhibiting a the holy administration for Him who put all in subjection to Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:8
verses.text: Wherefore also all men are His; some through knowledge, and others not yet so; and some as friends, some as faithful servants, some as servants merely.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:9
verses.text: This is the Teacher, who trains the Gnostic by mysteries, and the believer by good hopes, and the hard of heart by corrective discipline through sensible operation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:10
verses.text: Thence His providence is in private, in public, and everywhere.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:11
verses.text: And that He whom we call Saviour and Lord is the Son of God, the prophetic Scriptures explicitly prove.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:12
verses.text: So the Lord of all, of Greeks and of Barbarians, persuades those who are willing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:13
verses.text: For He does not compel him who (through choosing and fulfilling, from Him, what pertains to laying hold of it the hope) is able to receive salvation from Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:14
verses.text: It is He who also gave philosophy to the Greeks by means of the inferior angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:15
verses.text: For by an ancient and divine order the angels are distributed among the nations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:16
verses.text: But the glory of those who believe is "the Lord's portion".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:17
verses.text: For either the Lord does not care for all men; and this is the case either because He is unable (which is not to be thought, for it would be a proof of weakness), or because He is unwilling, which is not the attribute of a good being.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:18
verses.text: And He who for our sakes assumed flesh capable of suffering, is far from being luxuriously indolent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:19
verses.text: Or He does care for all, which is befitting for Him who has become Lord of all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:20
verses.text: For He is Saviour; not the Saviour of some, and of others not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:21
verses.text: But in proportion to the adaptation possessed by each, He has dispensed His beneficence both to Greeks and Barbarians, even to those of them that were predestinated, and in due time called, the faithful and elect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:22
verses.text: Nor can He who called all equally, and assigned special honours to those who have believed in a specially excellent way, ever envy any.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:23
verses.text: Nor can He who is the Lord of all, and serves above all the will of the good and almighty Father, ever be hindered  by another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:24
verses.text: But neither does envy touch the Lord, who without beginning was impassible; nor are the things of men such as to be envied by the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:25
verses.text: But it is another, he whom passion hath touched, who envies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:26
verses.text: And it cannot be said that it is from ignorance that the Lord is not willing to save humanity, because He knows not how each one is to be cared for.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:27
verses.text: For ignorance applies not to the God who, before the foundation of the world, was the counsellor of the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:28
verses.text: For He was the Wisdom "in which" the Sovereign God "delighted".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:29
verses.text: For the Son is the power of God, as being the Father's most ancient Word before the production of all things, and His Wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:30
verses.text: He is then properly called the Teacher of the beings formed by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:31
verses.text: Nor does He ever abandon care for men, by being drawn aside from pleasure, who, having assumed flesh, which by nature is susceptible of suffering, trained it to the condition of impassibility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:32
verses.text: And how is He Saviour and Lord, if not the Saviour and Lord of all? But He is the Saviour of those who have believed, because of their wishing to know; and the Lord of those who have not believed, till, being enabled to confess him, they obtain the peculiar and appropriate boon which comes by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:33
verses.text: Now the energy of the Lord has a reference to the Almighty; and the Son is, so to speak, an energy of the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:34
verses.text: Therefore, a hater of man, the Saviour can never be; who, for His exceeding love to human flesh, despising not its susceptibility to suffering, but investing Himself with it, came for the common salvation of men; for the faith of those who have chosen it, is common.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:35
verses.text: Nay more, He will never neglect His own work, because man alone of all the other living creatures was in his creation endowed with a conception of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:36
verses.text: Nor can there be any other better and more suitable government for men than that which is appointed by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:37
verses.text: It is then always proper for the one who is superior by nature to be over the inferior, and for him who is capable of managing aught well to have the management of it assigned to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:38
verses.text: Now that which truly rules and presides is the Divine Word and His providence, which inspects all things, and despises the care of nothing belonging to it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:39
verses.text: Those, then, who choose to belong to Him, are those who are perfected through faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:40
verses.text: He, the Son, is, by the will of the Almighty Father, the cause of all good things, being the first efficient cause of motion—a power incapable of being apprehended by sensation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:41
verses.text: For what He was, was not seen by those who, through the weakness of the flesh, were incapable of taking in the reality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:42
verses.text: But, having assumed sensitive flesh, He came to show man what was possible through obedience to the commandments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:43
verses.text: Being, then, the Father's power, He easily prevails in what He wishes, leaving not even the minutest point of His administration unattended to.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:44
verses.text: For otherwise the whole would not have been well executed by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:45
verses.text: But, as I think, characteristic of the highest power is the accurate scrutiny of all the parts, reaching even to the minutest, terminating in the first Administrator of the universe, who by the will of the Father directs the salvation of all; some overlooking, who are set under others, who are set over them, till you come to the great High Priest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:46
verses.text: For on one original first Principle, which acts according to the Father's will, the first and the second and the third depend.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:47
verses.text: Then at the highest extremity of the visible world is the blessed band of angels; and down to ourselves there are ranged, some under others, those who, from One and by One, both are saved and save.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:48
verses.text: As, then, the minutest particle of steel is moved by the spirit of the Heraclean stone, when diffused over many steel rings; so also, attracted by the Holy Spirit, the virtuous are added by affinity to the first abode, and the others in succession down to the last.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:49
verses.text: But those who are bad from infirmity, having fallen from vicious insatiableness into a depraved state, neither controlling nor controlled, rush round and round, whirled about by the passions, and fall down to the ground.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:50
verses.text: For this was the law from the first, that virtue should be the object of voluntary choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:51
verses.text: Wherefore also the commandments, according to the Law, and before the Law, not given to the upright (for the law is not appointed for a righteous man), ordained that he should receive eternal life and the blessed prize, who chose them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:52
verses.text: But, on the other hand, they allowed him who had been delighted with vice to consort with the objects of his choice; and, on the other hand, that the soul, which is ever improving in the acquisition of virtue and the increase of righteousness, should obtain a better place in the universe, as tending in each step of advancement towards the habit of impassibility, till "it come to a perfect man," to the excellence at once of knowledge and of inheritance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:53
verses.text: These salutary revolutions, in accordance with the order of change, are distinguished both by times, and places, and honours, and cognitions, and heritages, and ministries, according to the  particular order of each change, up to the transcendent and continual contemplation of the Lord in eternity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:54
verses.text: Now that which is lovable leads, to the contemplation of itself, each one who, from love of knowledge, applies himself entirely to contemplation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:55
verses.text: Wherefore also the Lord, drawing the commandments, both the first which He gave, and the second, from one fountain, neither allowed those who were before the law to be without law, nor permitted those who were unacquainted with the principles of the Barbarian philosophy to be without restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:56
verses.text: For, having furnished the one with the commandments, and the other with philosophy, He shut up unbelief to the Advent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:57
verses.text: Whence every one who believes not is without excuse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:58
verses.text: For by a different process of advancement, both Greek and Barbarian, He leads to the perfection which is by faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:59
verses.text: And if any one of the Greeks, passing over the preliminary training of the Hellenic philosophy, proceeds directly to the true teaching, he distances others, though an unlettered man, by choosing the compendious process of salvation by faith to perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:60
verses.text: Everything, then, which did not hinder a man's choice from being free, He made and rendered auxiliary to virtue, in order that there might be revealed somehow or other, even to those capable of seeing but dimly, the one only almighty, good God—from eternity to eternity saving by His Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:61
verses.text: And, on the other hand, He is in no respect whatever the cause of evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:62
verses.text: For all things are arranged with a view to the salvation of the universe by the Lord of the universe, both generally and particularly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:63
verses.text: It is then the function of the righteousness of salvation to improve everything as far as practicable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:64
verses.text: For even minor matters are arranged with a view to the salvation of that which is better, and for an abode suitable for people's character.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:65
verses.text: Now everything that is virtuous changes for the better; having as the proper cause of change the free choice of knowledge, which the soul has in its own power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 2:66
verses.text: But necessary corrections, through the goodness of the great overseeing Judge, both by the attendant angels, and by various acts of anticipative judgment, and by the perfect judgment, compel egregious sinners to repent.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—The Gnostic Aims at the Nearest Likeness Possible to God and His Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:2
verses.text: Now I pass over other things in silence, glorifying the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:3
verses.text: But I affirm that gnostic souls, that surpass in the grandeur of contemplation the mode of life of each of the holy ranks, among whom the blessed abodes of the gods are allotted by distribution, reckoned holy among the holy, transferred entire from among the entire, reaching places better than the better places, embracing the divine vision not in mirrors or by means of mirrors, but in the transcendently clear and absolutely pure insatiable vision which is the privilege of intensely loving souls, holding festival through endless ages, remain honoured with the indentity of all excellence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:4
verses.text: Such is the vision attainable by "the pure in heart".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:5
verses.text: This is the function of the Gnostic, who has been perfected, to have converse with God through the great High Priest, being made like the Lord, up to the measure of his capacity, in the whole service of God, which tends to the salvation of men, through care of the beneficence which has us for its object; and on the other side through worship, through teaching and through beneficence in deeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:6
verses.text: The Gnostic even forms and creates himself; and besides also, he, like to God, adorns those who hear him; assimilating as far as possible the moderation which, arising from practice, tends to impassibility, to Him who by nature possesses impassibility; and especially having uninterrupted converse and fellowship with the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:7
verses.text: Mildness, I think, and philanthropy, and eminent piety, are the rules of gnostic assimilation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:8
verses.text: I affirm that these virtues "are a sacrifice acceptable in the sight of God;" Scripture alleging that "the humble heart with right knowledge is the holocaust of God;" each man who is admitted to holiness being illuminated in order to indissoluble union.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:9
verses.text: For "to bring themselves into captivity," and to slay themselves, putting to death "the old man, who is through lusts corrupt," and raising the new man from death, "from the old conversation," by abandoning the passions, and becoming free of sin, both the Gospel and the apostle enjoin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:10
verses.text: It was this, consequently, which the Law intimated, by ordering the sinner to be cut off, and translated from death to life, to the impassibility that is the result of faith; which the teachers of the Law, not comprehending, inasmuch as they regarded the law as contentious, they have given a handle to those who attempt idly to calumniate the Law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:11
verses.text: And for this reason we rightly do not sacrifice to God, who, needing  nothing, supplies all men with all things; but we glorify Him who gave Himself in sacrifice for us, we also sacrificing ourselves; from that which needs nothing to that which needs nothing, and to that which is impassible from that which is impassible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:12
verses.text: For in our salvation alone God delights.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:13
verses.text: We do not therefore, and with reason too, offer sacrifice to Him who is not overcome by pleasures, inasmuch as the fumes of the smoke stop far beneath, and do not even reach the thickest clouds; but those they reach are far from them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:14
verses.text: The Deity neither is, then, in want of aught, nor loves pleasure, or gain, or money, being full, and supplying all things to everything that has received being and has wants.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:15
verses.text: And neither by sacrifices nor offerings, nor on the other hand by glory and honour, is the Deity won over; nor is He influenced by any such things; but He appears only to excellent and good men, who will never betray justice for threatened fear, nor by the promise of considerable gifts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:16
verses.text: But those who have not seen the self-determination of the human soul, and its incapability of being treated as a slave in what respects the choice of life, being disgusted at what is done through rude injustice, do not think that there is a God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:17
verses.text: On a par with these in opinion, are they who, falling into licentiousness in pleasures, and grievous pains, and unlooked-for accidents, and bidding defiance to events, say that there is no God, or that, though existing, He does not oversee all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:18
verses.text: And others there are, who are persuaded that those they reckon gods are capable of being prevailed upon by sacrifices and gifts, favouring, so to speak, their profligacies; and will not believe that He is the only true God, who exists in the invariableness of righteous goodness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:19
verses.text: The Gnostic, then, is pious, who cares first for himself, then for his neighbours, that they may become very good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:20
verses.text: For the son gratifies a good father, by showing himself good and like his father; and in like manner the subject, the governor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:21
verses.text: For believing and obeying are in our own power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:22
verses.text: But should any one suppose the cause of evils to be the weakness of matter, and the involuntary impulses of ignorance, and (in his stupidity) irrational necessities; he who has become a Gnostic has through instruction superiority over these, as if they were wild beasts; and in imitation of the divine plan, he does good to such as are willing, as far as he can.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:23
verses.text: And if ever placed in authority, like Moses, he will rule for the salvation of the governed; and will tame wildness and faithlessness, by recording honour for the most excellent, and punishment for the wicked, in accordance with reason for the sake of discipline.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:24
verses.text: For pre-eminently a divine image, resembling God, is the soul of a righteous man; in which, through obedience to the commands, as in a consecrated spot, is enclosed and enshrined the Leader of mortals and of immortals, King and Parent of what is good, who is truly law, and right, and eternal Word, being the one Saviour individually to each, and in common to all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:25
verses.text: He is the true Only-begotten, the express image of the glory of the universal King and Almighty Father, who impresses on the Gnostic the seal of the perfect contemplation, according to His own image; so that there is now a third divine image, made as far as possible like the Second Cause, the Essential Life, through which we live the true life; the Gnostic, as we regard him, being described as moving amid things sure and wholly immutable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:26
verses.text: Ruling, then, over himself and what belongs to him, and possessing a sure grasp, of divine science, he makes a genuine approach to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:27
verses.text: For the knowledge and apprehension of intellectual objects must necessarily be called certain scientific knowledge, whose function in reference to divine things is to consider what is the First Cause, and what that "by whom all things were made, and without whom nothing was made;" and what things, on the other hand, are as pervasive, and what is comprehensive; what conjoined, what disjoined; and what is the position which each one of them holds, and what power and what service each contributes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:28
verses.text: And again, among human things, what man himself is, and what he has naturally or preternaturally; and how, again, it becomes him to do or to suffer; and what are his virtues and what his vices; and about things good, bad, and indifferent; also about fortitude, and prudence, and self-restraint, and the virtue which is in all respects complete, namely, righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:29
verses.text: Further, he employs prudence and righteousness in the acquisition of wisdom, and fortitude, not only in the endurance of circumstances, but also in restraining pleasure and desire, grief and anger; and, in general, to withstand everything which either by any force or fraud entices us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:30
verses.text: For it is not necessary to endure vices and virtues, but it is to be persuaded to bear things that inspire fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:31
verses.text: Accordingly, pain is found beneficial in the healing art, and in discipline, and in punishment; and by it men's manners are corrected to their advantage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:32
verses.text: Forms of fortitude are endurance, magnanimity, high spirit, liberality, and grandeur.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:33
verses.text: And for this reason he neither meets with the blame or the bad opinion of the multitude; nor is he subjected to opinions or flatteries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:34
verses.text: But in  the indurance of toils and at the same time in the discharge of any duty, and in his manly superiority to all circumstances, he appears truly a man (ἀνήρ) among the rest of human beings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:35
verses.text: And, on the other hand, maintaining prudence, he exercises moderation in the calmness of his soul; receptive of what is commanded, as of what belongs to him, entertaining aversion to what is base, as alien to him; become decorous and supramundane, he does everything with decorum and in order, and transgresses in no respect, and in nothing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:36
verses.text: Rich he is in the highest degree in desiring nothing, as having few wants; and being in the midst of abundance of all good through the knowledge of the good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:37
verses.text: For it is the first effect of his righteousness, to love to spend his time and associate with those of his own race both in earth and heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:38
verses.text: So also he is liberal of what he possesses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:39
verses.text: And being a lover of men, he is a hater of the wicked, entertaining a perfect aversion to all villany.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:40
verses.text: He must consequently learn to be faithful both to himself and his neighbours, and obedient to the commandments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:41
verses.text: For he is the true servant of God who spontaneously subjects himself to His commands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:42
verses.text: And he who already, not through the commandments, but through knowledge itself, is pure in heart, is the friend of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:43
verses.text: For neither are we born by nature possessing virtue, nor after we are born does it grow naturally, as certain parts of the body; since then it would neither be voluntary nor praiseworthy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:44
verses.text: Nor is virtue, like speech, perfected by the practice that results from everyday occurrences (for this is very much the way in which vice originates).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:45
verses.text: For it is not by any art, either those of acquisition, or those which relate to the care of the body, that knowledge is attained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:46
verses.text: No more is it from the curriculum of instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:47
verses.text: For that is satisfied if it can only prepare and sharpen the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:48
verses.text: For the laws of the state are perchance able to restrain bad actions; but persuasive words, which but touch the surface, cannot produce a scientific permanence of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:49
verses.text: Now the Greek philosophy, as it were, purges the soul, and prepares it beforehand for the reception of faith, on which the Truth builds up the edifice of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:50
verses.text: This is the true athlete—he who in the great stadium, the fair world, is crowned for the true victory over all the passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:51
verses.text: For He who prescribes the contest is the Almighty God, and He who awards the prize is the only-begotten Son of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:52
verses.text: Angels and gods are spectators; and the contest, embracing all the varied exercises, is "not against flesh and blood," but against the spiritual powers of inordinate passions that work through the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:53
verses.text: He who obtains the mastery in these struggles, and overthrows the tempter, menacing, as it were, with certain contests, wins immortality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:54
verses.text: For the sentence of God in most righteous judgment is infallible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:55
verses.text: The spectators are summoned to the contest, and the athletes contend in the stadium; the one, who has obeyed the directions of the trainer, wins the day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:56
verses.text: For to all, all rewards proposed by God are equal; and He Himself is unimpeachable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:57
verses.text: And he who has power receives mercy, and he that has exercised will is mighty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:58
verses.text: So also we have received mind, that we may know what we do.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:59
verses.text: And the maxim "Know thyself" means here to know for what we are born.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:60
verses.text: And we are born to obey the commandments, if we choose to be willing to be saved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:61
verses.text: Such is the Nemesis, through which there is no escaping from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:62
verses.text: Man's duty, then, is obedience to God, who has proclaimed salvation manifold by the commandments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:63
verses.text: And confession is thanksgiving.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:64
verses.text: For the beneficent first begins to do good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:65
verses.text: And he who on fitting considerations readily receives and keeps the commandments, is faithful (πιστός); and he who by love requites benefits as far as he is able, is already a friend.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:66
verses.text: One recompense on the part of men is of paramount importance—the doing of what is pleasing to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:67
verses.text: As being His own production, and a result akin to Himself, the Teacher and Saviour receives acts of assistance and of improvement on the part of men as a personal favour and honour; as also He regards the injuries inflicted on those who believe on Him as ingratitude and dishonour to Himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:68
verses.text: For what other dishonour can touch God? Wherefore it is impossible to render a recompense at all equivalent to the boon received from the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:69
verses.text: And as those who maltreat property insult the owners, and those who maltreat soldiers insult the commander, so also the ill-usage of His consecrated ones is contempt for the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 3:70
verses.text: For, just as the sun not only illumines heaven and the whole world, shining over land and sea, but also through windows and small chinks sends his beams into the innermost recesses of houses, so the Word diffused everywhere casts His eye-glance on the minutest circumstances of the actions of life.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—The Heathens Made Gods Like Themselves, Whence Springs All Superstition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:2
verses.text: Now, as the Greeks represent the gods as possessing human forms, so also do they as possessing human passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:3
verses.text: And as each of them  depict their forms similar to themselves, as Xenophanes says, "Ethiopians as black and apes, the Thracians ruddy and tawny;" so also they assimilate their souls to those who form them: the Barbarians, for instance, who make them savage and wild; and the Greeks, who make them more civilized, yet subject to passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:4
verses.text: Wherefore it stands to reason, that the ideas entertained of God by wicked men must be bad, and those by good men most excellent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:5
verses.text: And therefore he who is in soul truly kingly and gnostic, being likewise pious and free from superstition, is persuaded that He who alone is God is honourable, venerable, august, beneficent, the doer of good, the author of all good things, but not the cause of evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:6
verses.text: And respecting the Hellenic superstition we have, as I think, shown enough in the book entitled by us The Exhortation, availing ourselves abundantly of the history bearing on the point.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:7
verses.text: There is no need, then, again to make a long story of what has already been clearly stated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:8
verses.text: But in as far as necessity requires to be pointed out on coming to the topic, suffice it to adduce a few out of many considerations in proof of the impiety of those who make the Divinity resemble the worst men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:9
verses.text: For either those Gods of theirs are injured by men, and are shown to be inferior to men on being injured by us; or, if not so, how is it that they are incensed at those by whom they are not injured, like a testy old wife roused to wrath?  As they say that Artemis was enraged at the aetolians on account of oeneus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:10
verses.text: For how, being a goddess, did she not consider that he had neglected to sacrifice, not through contempt, but out of inadvertence, or under the idea that he had sacrificed?  And Latona, arguing her case with Athene, on account of the latter being incensed at her for having brought forth in the temple, says:—  "Man-slaying spoils Torn from the dead you love to see.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:11
verses.text: And these To you are not unclean.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:12
verses.text: But you regard My parturition here a horrid thing, Though other creatures in the temple do No harm by bringing forth their young".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:13
verses.text: It is natural, then, that having a superstitious dread of those irascible gods, they imagine that all events are signs and causes of evils.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:14
verses.text: If a mouse bore through an altar built of clay, and for want of something else gnaw through an oil flask; if a cock that is being fattened crow in the evening, they determine this to be a sign of something.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:15
verses.text: Of such a one Menander gives a comic description in The Superstitious Man:—  "A.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:16
verses.text: Good luck be mine, ye honoured gods! Tying my, right shoe's string, I broke it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:17
Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:18
verses.text: Most likely, silly fool, For it was rotten, and you, niggard, you Would not buy new ones".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:19
verses.text: It was a clever remark of Antiphon, who (when one regarded it as an ill omen that the sow had eaten her pigs), on seeing her emaciated through the niggardliness of the person that kept her, said, Congratulate yourself on the omen that, being so hungry, she did not eat your own children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:20
verses.text: "And what wonder is it," says Bion, "if the mouse, finding nothing to eat, gnaws the bag?" For it were wonderful if (as Arcesilaus argued in fun) "the bag had eaten the mouse".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:21
verses.text: Diogenes accordingly remarked well to one who wondered at finding a serpent coiled round a pestle: "Don't wonder; for it would have been more surprising if you had seen the pestle coiled round the serpent, and the serpent straight".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:22
verses.text: For the irrational creatures must run, and scamper, and fight, and breed, and die; and these things being natural to them, can never be unnatural to us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:23
verses.text: "And many birds beneath the sunbeams walk".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:24
verses.text: And the comic poet Philemon treats such points in comedy:—  "When I see one who watches who has sneezed, Or who has spoke; or looking, who goes on, I straightway in the market sell him off.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:25
verses.text: Each one of us walks, talks, and sneezes too, For his own self, not for the citizens: According to their nature things turn out".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:26
verses.text: Then by the practice of temperance men seek health: and by cramming themselves, and wallowing in potations at feasts, they attract diseases.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:27
verses.text: There are many, too, that dread inscriptions set up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:28
verses.text: Very cleverly Diogenes, on finding in the house of a bad man the inscription, "Hercules, for victory famed, dwells here; let nothing bad enter," remarked, "And how shall the master of the house go in?"  The same people, who worship every stick and greasy stone, as the saying is, dreads tufts of tawny wool, and lumps of salt, and torches, and squills, and sulphur, bewitched by sorcerers, in certain impure rites of expiation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:29
verses.text: But God, the true God, recognises as holy only the character of the righteous man,—as unholy, wrong and wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:30
verses.text: You may see the eggs, taken from those who have been purified, hatched if subjected to the necessary warmth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:31
verses.text: But this could not take  place if they had had transferred to them the sins of the man that had undergone purification.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:32
verses.text: Accordingly the comic poet Diphilus facetiously writes, in comedy, of sorcerers, in the following words:—  "Purifying Proetus' daughters, and their father Proetus Abantades, and fifth, an old wife to boot, So many people's persons with one torch, one squill, With sulphur and asphalt of the loud-sounding sea, From the placid-flowing, deep-flowing ocean.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:33
verses.text: But blest air through the clouds send Anticyra That I may make this bug into a drone".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:34
verses.text: For well Menander remarks:—  "Had you, O Phidias, any real ill, You needs must seek for it a real cure; Now 'tis not so.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:35
verses.text: And for the unreal ill I've found an unreal cure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:36
verses.text: Believe that it Will do thee good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:37
verses.text: Let women in a ring Wipe thee, and from three fountains water bring.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:38
verses.text: Add salt and lentils; sprinkle then thyself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:39
verses.text: Each one is pure, who's conscious of no sin".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:40
verses.text: For instance, the tragedy says:—  Menelaus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:41
verses.text: "What disease, Orestes, is destroying thee?" Orestes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:42
verses.text: "Conscience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:43
verses.text: For horrid deeds I know I've done".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:44
verses.text: For in reality there is no other purity but abstinence from sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:45
verses.text: Excellently then Epicharmus says:—  "If a pure mind thou hast, In thy whole body thou art pure".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:46
verses.text: Now also we say that it is requisite to purify the soul from corrupt and bad doctrines by right reason; and so thereafter to the recollection of the principal heads of doctrine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 4:47
verses.text: Since also before the communication of the mysteries they think it right to apply certain purifications to those who are to be initiated; so it is requisite for men to abandon impious opinion, and thus turn to the true tradition.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—The Holy Soul a More Excellent Temple Than Any Edifice Built by Man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:2
verses.text: For is it not the case that rightly and truly we do not circumscribe in any place that which cannot be circumscribed; nor do we shut up in temples made with hands that which contains all things? What work of builders, and stonecutters, and mechanical art can be holy? Superior to these are not they who think that the air, and the enclosing space, or rather the whole world and the universe, are meet for the excellency of God?  It were indeed ridiculous, as the philosophers themselves say, for man, the plaything of God, to make God, and for God to be the plaything of art; since what is made is similar and the same to that of which it is made, as that which is made of ivory is ivory, and that which is made of gold golden.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:3
verses.text: Now the images and temples constructed by mechanics are made of inert matter; so that they too are inert, and material, and profane; and if you perfect the art, they partake of mechanical coarseness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:4
verses.text: Works of art cannot then be sacred and divine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:5
verses.text: And what can be localized, there being nothing that is not localized? Since all things are in a place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:6
verses.text: And that which is localized having been formerly not localized, is localized by something.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:7
verses.text: If, then, God is localized by men, He was once not localized, and did not exist at all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:8
verses.text: For the non-existent is what is not localized; since whatever does not exist is not localized.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:9
verses.text: And what exists cannot be localized by what does not exist; nor by another entity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:10
verses.text: For it is also an entity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:11
verses.text: It follows that it must be by itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:12
verses.text: And how shall anything generate itself? Or how shall that which exists place itself as to being? Whether, being formerly not localized, has it localized itself? But it was not in existence; since what exists not is not localized.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:13
verses.text: And its localization being supposed, how can it afterwards make itself what it previously was?  But how can He, to whom the things that are belong, need anything? But were God possessed of a human form, He would need, equally with man, food, and shelter, and house, and the attendant incidents.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:14
verses.text: Those who are like in form and affections will require similar sustenance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:15
verses.text: And if sacred (το ἱερόν) has a twofold application, designating both God Himself and the structure raised to His honour, how shall we not with propriety call the Church holy, through knowledge, made for the honour of God, sacred (ἱερόν) to God, of great value, and not constructed by mechanical art, nor embellished by the hand of an impostor, but by the will of God fashioned into a temple? For it is not now the place, but the assemblage of the elect, that I call the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:16
verses.text: This temple is better for the reception of the greatness of the dignity of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:17
verses.text: For the living creature which is of high value, is made sacred by that which is worth all, or rather which has no equivalent, in virtue of the exceeding sanctity of the latter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:18
verses.text: Now this is the Gnostic, who is of great value, who is honoured by God, in whom God is enshrined, that is, the knowledge respecting God is consecrated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:19
verses.text: Here, too, we shall find the divine likeness and the holy image in the righteous soul, when it is blessed in being purified and performing blessed deeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:20
verses.text: Here also we shall find that which is localized, and that which is being localized,—the former in the case of those who are already Gnostics, and the latter in the case of those  capable of becoming so, although not yet worthy of receiving the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 5:21
verses.text: For every being destined to believe is already faithful in the sight of God, and set up for His honour, an image, endowed with virtue, dedicated to God.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—Prayers and Praise from a Pure Mind, Ceaselessly Offered, Far Better Than Sacrifices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:2
verses.text: As, then, God is not circumscribed by place, neither is ever represented by the form of a living creature; so neither has He similar passions, nor has He wants like the creatures, so as to desire sacrifice, from hunger, by way of food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:3
verses.text: Those creatures which are affected by passion are all mortal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:4
verses.text: And it is useless to bring food to one who is not nourished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:5
verses.text: And that comic poet Pherecrates, in The Fugitives, facetiously represents the gods themselves as finding fault with men on the score of their sacred rites:—  "When to the gods you sacrifice, Selecting what our portion is, 'Tis shame to tell, do ye not take, And both the thighs, clean to the groins, The loins quite bare, the backbone, too, Clean scrape as with a file, Them swallow, and the remnant give To us as if to dogs? And then, As if of one another 'shamed, With heaps of salted barley hide".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:6
verses.text: And Eubulus, also a comic poet, thus writes respecting sacrifices:—  "But to the gods the tail alone And thigh, as if to paederasts you sacrifice".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:7
verses.text: And introducing Dionysus in Semele, he represents him disputing:—  "First if they offer aught to me, there are Who offer blood, the bladder, not the heart Or caul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:8
verses.text: For I no flesh do ever eat That's sweeter than the thigh".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:9
verses.text: And Menander writes:—  "The end of the loin, The bile, the bones uneatable, they set Before the gods; the rest themselves consume".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:10
verses.text: For is not the savour of the holocausts avoided by the beasts? And if in reality the savour is the guerdon of the gods of the Greeks, should they not first deify the cooks, who are dignified with equal happiness, and worship the chimney itself, which is closer still to the much-prized savour?  And Hesiod says that Zeus, cheated in a division of flesh by Prometheus, received the white bones of an ox, concealed with cunning art, in shining fat:—  "Whence to the immortal gods the tribes of men The victim's white bones on the altars burn".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:11
verses.text: But they will by no means say that the Deity, enfeebled through the desire that springs from want, is nourished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:12
verses.text: Accordingly, they will represent Him as nourished without desire like a plant, and like beasts that burrow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:13
verses.text: They say that these grow innoxiously, nourished either by the density in the air, or from the exhalations proceeding from their own body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:14
verses.text: Though if the Deity, though needing nothing, is according to them nourished, what necessity has He for food, wanting nothing? But if, by nature needing nothing, He delights to be honoured, it is not without reason that we honour God in prayer; and thus the best and holiest sacrifice with righteousness we bring, presenting it as an offering to the most righteous Word, by whom we receive knowledge, giving glory by Him for what we have learned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:15
verses.text: The altar, then, that is with us here, the terrestrial one, is the congregation of those who devote themselves to prayers, having as it were one common voice and one mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:16
verses.text: Now, if nourishing substances taken in by the nostrils are diviner than those taken in by the mouth, yet they infer respiration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:17
verses.text: What, then, do they say of God? Whether does He exhale like the tribe of oaks? Or does He only inhale, like the aquatic animals, by the dilatation of their gills? Or does He breathe all round, like the insects, by the compression of the section by means of their wings? But no one, if he is in his senses, will liken God to any of these.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:18
verses.text: And the creatures that breathe by the expansion of the lung towards the thorax draw in the air.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:19
verses.text: Then if they assign to God viscera, and arteries, and veins, and nerves, and parts, they will make Him in nothing different from man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:20
verses.text: Now breathing together (σύμπνοια) is properly said of the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:21
verses.text: For the sacrifice of the Church is the word breathing as incense from holy souls, the sacrifice and the whole mind being at the same time unveiled to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:22
verses.text: Now the very ancient altar in Delos they celebrated as holy; which alone, being undefiled by slaughter and death, they say Pythagoras approached.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:23
verses.text: And will they not believe us when we say that the righteous soul is the truly sacred altar, and that incense arising from it is holy prayer? But I believe sacrifices were invented by men to be a pretext for eating flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:24
verses.text: But without such idolatry he who wished might have partaken of flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:25
verses.text: For the sacrifices of the Law express figuratively  the piety which we practice, as the turtle-dove and the pigeon offered for sins point out that the cleansing of the irrational part of the soul is acceptable to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:26
verses.text: But if any one of the righteous does not burden his soul by the eating of flesh, he has the advantage of a rational reason, not as Pythagoras and his followers dream of the transmigration of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:27
verses.text: Now Xenocrates, treating by himself of "the food derived from animals," and Polemon in his work On Life according to Nature, seem clearly to say that animal food is unwholesome, inasmuch as it has already been elaborated and assimilated to the souls of the irrational creatures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:28
verses.text: So also, in particular, the Jews abstain from swine's flesh on the ground of this animal being unclean; since more than the other animals it roots up, and destroys the productions of the ground.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:29
verses.text: But if they say that the animals were assigned to men—and we agree with them—yet it was not entirely for food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:30
verses.text: Nor was it all animals, but such as do not work.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:31
verses.text: Wherefore the comic poet Plato says not badly in the drama of The Feasts: —  "For of the quadrupeds we should not slay In future aught but swine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:32
verses.text: For these have flesh Most toothsome; and about the pig is nought For us, excepting bristles, mud, and noise".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:33
verses.text: Whence aesop said not badly, that "swine squeaked out very loudly, because, when they were dragged, they knew that they were good for nothing but for sacrifice".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:34
verses.text: Wherefore also Cleanthes says, "that they have soul instead of salt," that their flesh may not putrefy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:35
verses.text: Some, then, eat them as useless, others as destructive of fruits.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:36
verses.text: And others do not eat them, because the animal has a strong sensual propensity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:37
verses.text: So, then, the law sacrifices not the goat, except in the sole case of the banishment of sins; since pleasure is the metropolis of vice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:38
verses.text: It is to the point also that it is said that the eating of goat's flesh contributes to epilepsy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:39
verses.text: And they say that the greatest increase is produced by swine's flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:40
verses.text: Wherefore it is beneficial to those who exercise the body; but to those who devote themselves to the development of the soul it is not so, on account of the hebetude that results from the eating of flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:41
verses.text: Perchance also some Gnostic will abstain from the eating of flesh for the sake of training, and in order that the flesh may not grow wanton in amorousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:42
verses.text: "For wine," says Androcydes, "and gluttonous feeds of flesh make the body strong, but the soul more sluggish".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:43
verses.text: Accordingly such food, in order to clear understanding, is to be rejected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:44
verses.text: Wherefore also the Egyptians, in the purifications practiced among them, do not allow the priests to feed on flesh; but they use chickens, as lightest; and they do not touch fish, on account of certain fables, but especially on account of such food making the flesh flabby.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:45
verses.text: But now terrestrial animals and birds breathe the same air as our vital spirits, being possessed of a vital principle cognate with the air.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:46
verses.text: But it is said that fishes do not breathe this air, but that which was mixed with the water at the instant of its first creation, as well as with the rest of the elements, which is also a sign of the permanence of matter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:47
verses.text: Wherefore we ought to offer to God sacrifices not costly, but such as He loves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:48
verses.text: And that compounded incense which is mentioned in the Law, is that which consists of many tongues and voices in prayer, or rather of different nations and natures, prepared by the gift vouchsafed in the dispensation for "the unity of the faith," and brought together in praises, with a pure mind, and just and right conduct, from holy works and righteous prayer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 6:49
verses.text: For in the elegant language of poetry,—  "Who is so great a fool, and among men So very easy of belief, as thinks The gods, with fraud of fleshless bones and bile All burnt, not fit for hungry dogs to eat, Delighted are, and take this as their prize, And favour show to those who treat them thus,"  though they happen to be tyrants and robbers?  But we say that the fire sanctifies not flesh, but sinful souls; meaning not the all-devouring vulgar fire but that of wisdom, which pervades the soul passing through the fire.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—What Sort of Prayer the Gnostic Employs, and How It is Heard by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:2
verses.text: Now we are commanded to reverence and to honour the same one, being persuaded that He is Word, Saviour, and Leader, and by Him, the Father, not on special days, as some others, but doing this continually in our whole life, and in every way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:3
verses.text: Certainly the elect race justified by the precept says, "Seven times a day have I praised Thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:4
verses.text: Whence not in a specified place, or selected temple, or at certain festivals and on appointed days, but during his whole life, the Gnostic in every place, even if he be alone by himself, and wherever he has any of those who have exercised the like faith, honours God,  that is, acknowledges his gratitude for the knowledge of the way to live.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:5
verses.text: And if the presence of a good man, through the respect and reverence which he inspires, always improves him with whom he associates, with much more reason does not he who always holds uninterrupted converse with God by knowledge, life, and thanksgiving, grow at every step superior to himself in all respects—in conduct, in words, in disposition? Such an one is persuaded that God is ever beside him, and does not suppose that He is confined in certain limited places; so that under the idea that at times he is without Him, he may indulge in excesses night and day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:6
verses.text: Holding festival, then, in our whole life, persuaded that God is altogether on every side present, we cultivate our fields, praising; we sail the sea, hymning; in all the rest of our conversation we conduct ourselves according to rule.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:7
verses.text: The Gnostic, then, is very closely allied to God, being at once grave and cheerful in all things,—grave on account of the bent of his soul towards the Divinity, and cheerful on account of his consideration of the blessings of humanity which God hath given us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:8
verses.text: Now the excellence of knowledge is evidently presented by the prophet when he says, "Benignity, and instruction, and knowledge teach me," magnifying the supremacy of perfection by a climax.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:9
verses.text: He is, then, the truly kingly man; he is the sacred high priest of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:10
verses.text: And this is even now observed among the most sagacious of the Barbarians, in advancing the sacerdotal caste to the royal power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:11
verses.text: He, therefore, never surrenders himself to the rabble that rules supreme over the theatres, and gives no admittance even in a dream to the things which are spoken, done, and seen for the sake of alluring pleasures; neither, therefore, to the pleasures of sight, nor the various pleasures which are found in other enjoyments, as costly incense and odours, which bewitch the nostrils, or preparations of meats, and indulgences in different wines, which ensnare the palate, or fragrant bouquets of many flowers, which through the senses effeminate the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:12
verses.text: But always tracing up to God the grave enjoyment of all things, he offers the first-fruits of food, and drink, and unguents to the Giver of all, acknowledging his thanks in the gift and in the use of them by the Word given to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:13
verses.text: He rarely goes to convivial banquets of all and sundry, unless the announcement to him of the friendly and harmonious character of the entertainment induce him to go.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:14
verses.text: For he is convinced that God knows and perceives all things—not the words only, but also the thought; since even our sense of hearing, which acts through the passages of the body, has the apprehension belonging to it not through corporeal power, but through a psychical perception, and the intelligence which distinguishes significant sounds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:15
verses.text: God is not, then, possessed of human form, so as to hear; nor needs He senses, as the Stoics have decided, "especially hearing and sight; for He could never otherwise apprehend".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:16
verses.text: But the susceptibility of the air, and the intensely keen perception of the angels, and the power which reaches the soul's consciousness, by ineffable power and without sensible hearing, know all things at the moment of thought.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:17
verses.text: And should any one say that the voice does not reach God, but is rolled downwards in the air, yet the thoughts of the saints cleave not the air only, but the whole world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:18
verses.text: And the divine power, with the speed of light, sees through the whole soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:19
verses.text: Well! Do not also volitions speak to God, uttering their voice? And are they not conveyed by conscience? And what voice shall He wait for, who, according to His purpose, knows the elect already, even before his birth, knows what is to be as already existent? Does not the light of power shine down to the very bottom of the whole soul; "the lamp of knowledge," as the Scripture says, searching "the recesses"? God is all ear and all eye, if we may be permitted to use these expressions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:20
verses.text: In general, then, an unworthy opinion of God preserves no piety, either in hymns, or discourses, or writings, or dogmas, but diverts to grovelling and unseemly ideas and notions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:21
verses.text: Whence the commendation of the multitude differs nothing from censure, in consequence of their ignorance of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:22
verses.text: The objects, then, of desires and aspirations, and, in a word, of the mind's impulses, are the subjects of prayers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:23
verses.text: Wherefore, no man desires a draught, but to drink what is drinkable; and no man desires an inheritance, but to inherit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:24
verses.text: And in like manner no man desires knowledge, but to know; or a right government, but to take part in the government.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:25
verses.text: The subjects of our prayers, then, are the subjects of our requests, and the subjects of requests are the objects of desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:26
verses.text: Prayer, then, and desire, follow in order, with the view of possessing the blessings and advantages offered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:27
verses.text: The Gnostic, then, who is such by possession, makes his prayer and request for the truly good things which appertain to the soul, and prays, he himself also contributing his efforts to attain to the habit of goodness, so as no longer to have the things that are good as certain lessons belonging to him, but to be good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:28
verses.text: Wherefore also it is most incumbent on such  to pray, knowing as they do the Divinity rightly, and having the moral excellence suitable to him; who know what things are really good, and what are to be asked, and when and how in each individual case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:29
verses.text: It is the extremest stupidity to ask of them who are no gods, as if they were gods; or to ask those things which are not beneficial, begging evils for themselves under the appearance of good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:30
verses.text: Whence, as is right, there being only one good God, that some good things be given from Him alone, and that some remain, we and the angels pray.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:31
verses.text: But not similarly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:32
verses.text: For it is not the same thing to pray that the gift remain, and to endeavour to obtain it for the first time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:33
verses.text: The averting of evils is a species of prayer; but such prayer is never to be used for the injury of men, except that the Gnostic, in devoting attention to righteousness, may make use of this petition in the case of those who are past feeling.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:34
verses.text: Prayer is, then, to speak more boldly, converse with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:35
verses.text: Though whispering, consequently, and not opening the lips, we speak in silence, yet we cry inwardly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:36
verses.text: For God hears continually all the inward converse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:37
verses.text: So also we raise the head and lift the hands to heaven, and set the feet in motion at the closing utterance of the prayer, following the eagerness of the spirit directed towards the intellectual essence; and endeavouring to abstract the body from the earth, along with the discourse, raising the soul aloft, winged with longing for better things, we compel it to advance to the region of holiness, magnanimously despising the chain of the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:38
verses.text: For we know right well, that the Gnostic willingly passes over the whole world, as the Jews certainly did over Egypt, showing clearly, above all, that he will be as near as possible to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:39
