verses.text: Now, if some assign definite hours for prayer—as, for example, the third, and sixth, and ninth—yet the Gnostic prays throughout his whole life, endeavouring by prayer to have fellowship with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:40
verses.text: And, briefly, having reached to this, he leaves behind him all that is of no service, as having now received the perfection of the man that acts by love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:41
verses.text: But the distribution of the hours into a threefold division, honoured with as many prayers, those are acquainted with, who know the blessed triad of the holy abodes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:42
verses.text: Having got to this point, I recollect the doctrines about there being no necessity to pray, introduced by certain of the heterodox, that is, the followers of the heresy of Prodicus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:43
verses.text: That they may not then be inflated with conceit about this godless wisdom of theirs, as if it were strange, let them learn that it was embraced before by the philosophers called Cyrenaics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:44
verses.text: Nevertheless, the unholy knowledge (gnosis) of those falsely called Gnostics shall meet with confutation at a fitting time; so that the assault on them, by no means brief, may not, by being introduced into the commentary, break the discourse in hand, in which we are showing that the only really holy and pious man is he who is truly a Gnostic according to the rule of the Church, to whom alone the petition made in accordance with the will of God is granted, on asking and on thinking.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:45
verses.text: For as God can do all that He wishes, so the Gnostic receives all that he asks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:46
verses.text: For, universally, God knows those who are and those who are not worthy of good things; whence He gives to each what is suitable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:47
verses.text: Wherefore to those that are unworthy, though they ask often, He will not give; but He will give to those who are worthy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:48
verses.text: Nor is petition superfluous, though good things are given without claim.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:49
verses.text: Now thanksgiving and request for the conversion of our neighbours is the function of the Gnostic; as also the Lord prayed, giving thanks for the accomplishment of His ministry, praying that as many as possible might attain to knowledge; that in the saved, by salvation, through knowledge, God might be glorified, and He who is alone good and alone Saviour might be acknowledged through the Son from age to age.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:50
verses.text: But also faith, that one will receive, is a species of prayer gnostically laid up in store.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:51
verses.text: But if any occasion of converse with God becomes prayer, no opportunity of access to God ought to be omitted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:52
verses.text: Without doubt, the holiness of the Gnostic, in union with God's blessed Providence, exhibits in voluntary confession the perfect beneficence of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:53
verses.text: For the holiness of the Gnostic, and the reciprocal benevolence of the friend of God, are a kind of corresponding movement of providence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:54
verses.text: For neither is God involuntarily good, as the fire is warming; but in Him the imparting of good things is voluntary, even if He receive the request previously.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:55
verses.text: Nor shall he who is saved be saved against his will, for he is not inanimate; but he will above all voluntarily and of free choice speed to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:56
verses.text: Wherefore also man received the commandments in order that he might be self-impelled, to whatever he wished of things to be chosen and to be avoided.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:57
verses.text: Wherefore God does not do good by necessity, but from His free choice benefits those  who spontaneously turn.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:58
verses.text: For the Providence which extends to us from God is not ministerial, as that service which proceeds from inferiors to superiors.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:59
verses.text: But in pity for our weakness, the continual dispensations of Providence work, as the care of shepherds towards the sheep, and of a king towards his subjects; we ourselves also conducting ourselves obediently towards our superiors, who take the management of us, as appointed, in accordance with the commission from God with which they are invested.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:60
verses.text: Consequently those who render the most free and kingly service, which is the result of a pious mind and of knowledge, are servants and attendants of the Divinity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:61
verses.text: Each place, then, and time, in which we entertain the idea of God, is in reality sacred.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:62
verses.text: When, then, the man who chooses what is right, and is at the same time of thankful heart, makes his request in prayer, he contributes to the obtaining of it, gladly taking hold in prayer of the thing desired.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:63
verses.text: For when the Giver of good things perceives the susceptibility on our part, all good things follow at once the conception of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:64
verses.text: Certainly in prayer the character is sifted, how it stands with respect to duty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:65
verses.text: But if voice and expression are given us, for the sake of understanding, how can God not hear the soul itself, and the mind, since assuredly soul hears soul, and mind, mind? Whence God does not wait for loquacious tongues, as interpreters among men, but knows absolutely the thoughts of all; and what the voice intimates to us, that our thought, which even before the creation He knew would come into our mind, speaks to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:66
verses.text: Prayer, then, may be uttered without the voice, by concentrating the whole spiritual nature within on expression by the mind, in un-distracted turning towards God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:67
verses.text: And since the dawn is an image of the day of birth, and from that point the light which has shone forth at first from the darkness increases, there has also dawned on those involved in darkness a day of the knowledge of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:68
verses.text: In correspondence with the manner of the sun's rising, prayers are made looking towards the sunrise in the east.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:69
verses.text: Whence also the most ancient temples looked towards the west, that people might be taught to turn to the east when facing the images.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:70
verses.text: "Let my prayer be directed before Thee as incense, the uplifting of my hands as the evening sacrifice," say the Psalms.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:71
verses.text: In the case of wicked men, therefore, prayer is most injurious, not to others alone, but to themselves also.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:72
verses.text: If, then, they should ask and receive what they call pieces of good fortune, these injure them after they receive them, being ignorant how to use them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:73
verses.text: For they pray to possess what they have not, and they ask things which seem, but are not, good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:74
verses.text: But the Gnostic will ask the permanence of the things he possesses, adaptation for what is to take place, and the eternity of those things which he shall receive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:75
verses.text: And the things which are really good, the things which concern the soul, he prays that they may belong to him, and remain with him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:76
verses.text: And so he desires not anything that is absent, being content with what is present.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:77
verses.text: For he is not deficient in the good things which are proper to him; being already sufficient for himself, through divine grace and knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:78
verses.text: But having become sufficient in himself, he stands in no want of other things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:79
verses.text: But knowing the sovereign will, and possessing as soon as he prays, being brought into close contact with the almighty power, and earnestly desiring to be spiritual, through boundless love, he is united to the Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:80
verses.text: Thus he, being magnanimous, possessing, through knowledge, what is the most precious of all, the best of all, being quick in applying himself to contemplation, retains in his soul the permanent energy of the objects of his contemplation, that is the perspicacious keenness of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:81
verses.text: And this power he strives to his utmost to acquire, by obtaining command of all the influences which war against the mind; and by applying himself without intermission to speculation, by exercising himself in the training of abstinence from pleasures, and of right conduct in what he does; and besides, furnished with great experience both in study and in life, he has freedom of speech, not the power of a babbling tongue, but a power which employs plain language, and which neither for favour nor fear conceals aught of the things which may be worthily said at the fitting time, in which it is highly necessary to say them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:82
verses.text: He, then, having received the things respecting God from the mystic choir of the truth itself, employs language which urges the magnitude of virtue in accordance with its worth; and shows its results with an inspired elevation of prayer, being associated gnostically, as far as possible, with intellectual and spiritual objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:83
verses.text: Whence he is always mild and meek, accessible, affable, long-suffering, grateful, endued with a good conscience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:84
verses.text: Such a man is rigid, not alone so as not to be corrupted, but so as not to be tempted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:85
verses.text: For he never exposes his soul to submission, or capture at the hands of Pleasure and Pain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:86
verses.text: If the Word, who is Judge, call; he, having grown inflexible, and not indulging a whit the passions, walks unswervingly where justice advises him to go; being very well persuaded that all things are managed consummately well,  and that progress to what is better goes on in the case of souls that have chosen virtue, till they come to the Good itself, to the Father's vestibule, so to speak, close to the great High Priest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:87
verses.text: Such is our Gnostic, faithful, persuaded that the affairs of the universe are managed in the best way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:88
verses.text: Particularly, he is well pleased with all that happens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:89
verses.text: In accordance with reason, then, he asks for none of those things in life required for necessary use; being persuaded that God, who knows all things, supplies the good with whatever is for their benefit, even though they do not ask.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:90
verses.text: For my view is, that as all things are supplied to the man of art according to the rules of art, and to the Gentile in a Gentile way, so also to the Gnostic all things are supplied gnostically.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:91
verses.text: And the man who turns from among the Gentiles will ask for faith, while he that ascends to knowledge will ask for the perfection of love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:92
verses.text: And the Gnostic, who has reached the summit, will pray that contemplation may grow and abide, as the common man will for continual good health.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:93
verses.text: Nay, he will pray that he may never fall from virtue; giving his most strenuous co-operation in order that he may become infallible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:94
verses.text: For he knows that some of the angels, through carelessness, were hurled to the earth, not having yet quite reached that state of oneness, by extricating themselves from the propensity to that of duality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:95
verses.text: But him, who from this has trained himself to the summit of knowledge and the elevated height of the perfect man, all things relating to time and place help on, now that he has made it his choice to live infallibly, and subjects himself to training in order to the attainment of the stability of knowledge on each side.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:96
verses.text: But in the case of those in whom there is still a heavy corner, leaning downwards, even that part which has been elevated by faith is dragged down.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:97
verses.text: In him, then, who by gnostic training has acquired virtue which cannot be lost, habit becomes nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:98
verses.text: And just as weight in a stone, so the knowledge of such an one is incapable of being lost.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:99
verses.text: Not without, but through the exercise of will, and by the force of reason, and knowledge, and Providence, is it brought to become incapable of being lost.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:100
verses.text: Through care it becomes incapable of being lost.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:101
verses.text: He will employ caution so as to avoid sinning, and consideration to prevent the loss of virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:102
verses.text: Now knowledge appears to produce consideration, by teaching to perceive the things that are capable of contributing to the permanence of virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:103
verses.text: The highest thing is, then, the knowledge of God; wherefore also by it virtue is so preserved as to be incapable of being lost.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:104
verses.text: And he who knows God is holy and pious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:105
verses.text: The Gnostic has consequently been demonstrated by us to be the only pious man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:106
verses.text: He rejoices in good things present, and is glad on account of those promised, as if they were already present.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:107
verses.text: For they do not elude his notice, as if they were still absent, because he knows by anticipation what sort they are.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:108
verses.text: Being then persuaded by knowledge how each future thing shall be, he possesses it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:109
verses.text: For want and defect are measured with reference to what appertains to one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:110
verses.text: If, then, he possesses wisdom, and wisdom is a divine thing, he who partakes of what has no want will himself have no want.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:111
verses.text: For the imparting of wisdom does not take place by activity and receptivity moving and stopping each other, or by aught being abstracted or becoming defective.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:112
verses.text: Activity is therefore shown to be undiminished in the act of communication.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:113
verses.text: So, then, our Gnostic possesses all good things, as far as possible; but not likewise in number; since otherwise he would be incapable of changing his place through the due inspired stages of advancement and acts of administration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:114
verses.text: Him God helps, by honouring him with closer oversight.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:115
verses.text: For were not all things made for the sake of good men, for their possession and advantage, or rather salvation? He will not then deprive, of the things which exist for the sake of virtue, those for whose sake they were created.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:116
verses.text: For, evidently in honour of their excellent nature and their holy choice, he inspires those who have made choice of a good life with strength for the rest of their salvation; exhorting some, and helping others, who of themselves have become worthy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:117
verses.text: For all good is capable of being produced in the Gnostic; if indeed it is his aim to know and do everything intelligently.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:118
verses.text: And as the physician ministers health to those who co-operate with him in order to health, so also God ministers eternal salvation to those who co-operate for the attainment of knowledge and good conduct; and since what the commandments enjoin are in our own power, along with the performance of them, the promise is accomplished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:119
verses.text: And what follows seems to me to be excellently said by the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:120
verses.text: An athlete of no mean reputation among those of old, having for a long time subjected his body to thorough training in order to the attainment of manly strength, on going up to the Olympic games, cast his eye on the statue of the Pisaean Zeus, and said: "O Zeus, if all the requisite preparations for the contest have been made by me, come, give me the victory, as is right".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:121
verses.text: For so, in the case of the Gnostic, who has unblameably and with a good conscience fulfilled all that depends on him, in the direction of learning, and training, and well-doing, and pleasing God, the whole contributes to carry salvation on to perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:122
verses.text: From us, then, are demanded the things which  are in our own power, and of the things which pertain to us, both present and absent, the choice, and desire, and possession, and use, and permanence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:123
verses.text: Wherefore also he who holds converse with God must have his soul immaculate and stainlessly pure, it being essential to have made himself perfectly good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:124
verses.text: But also it becomes him to make all his prayers gently with the good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:125
verses.text: For it is a dangerous thing to take part in others' sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:126
verses.text: Accordingly the Gnostic will pray along with those who have more recently believed, for those things in respect of which it is their duty to act together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:127
verses.text: And his whole life is a holy festival.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:128
verses.text: His sacrifices are prayers, and praises, and readings in the Scriptures before meals, and psalms and hymns during meals and before bed, and prayers also again during night.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:129
verses.text: By these he unites himself to the divine choir, from continual recollection, engaged in contemplation which has everlasting remembrance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:130
verses.text: And what? Does he not also know the other kind of sacrifice, which consists in the giving both of doctrines and of money to those who need? Assuredly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:131
verses.text: But he does not use wordy prayer by his mouth; having learned to ask of the Lord what is requisite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:132
verses.text: In every place, therefore, but not ostensibly and visibly to the multitude, he will pray.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:133
verses.text: But while engaged in walking, in conversation, while in silence, while engaged in reading and in works according to reason, he in every mood prays.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:134
verses.text: If he but form the thought in the secret chamber of his soul, and call on the Father "with unspoken groanings," He is near, and is at his side, while yet speaking.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 7:135
verses.text: Inasmuch as there are but three ends of all action, he does everything for its excellence and utility; but doing aught for the sake of pleasure, he leaves to those who pursue the common life.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—The Gnostic So Addicted to Truth as Not to Need to Use an Oath.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:2
verses.text: The man of proved character in such piety is far from being apt to lie and to swear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:3
verses.text: For an oath is a decisive affirmation, with the taking of the divine name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:4
verses.text: For how can he, that is once faithful, show himself unfaithful, so as to require an oath; and so that his life may not be a sure and decisive oath? He lives, and walks, and shows the trustworthiness of his affirmation in an unwavering and sure life and speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:5
verses.text: And if the wrong lies in the judgment of one who does and says something, and not in the suffering of one who has been wronged, he will neither lie nor commit perjury so as to wrong the Deity, knowing that it by nature is incapable of being harmed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:6
verses.text: Nor yet will he lie or commit any transgression, for the sake of the neighbour whom he has learned to love, though he be not on terms of intimacy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:7
verses.text: Much more, consequently, will he not lie or perjure himself on his own account, since he never with his will can be found doing wrong to himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:8
verses.text: But he does not even swear, preferring to make averment, in affirmation by "yea," and in denial by "nay".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:9
verses.text: For it is an oath to swear, or to produce anything from the mind in the way of confirmation in the shape of an oath.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:10
verses.text: It suffices, then, with him, to add to an affirmation or denial the expression "I say truly," for confirmation to those who do not perceive the certainty of his answer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:11
verses.text: For he ought, I think, to maintain a life calculated to inspire confidence towards those without, so that an oath may not even be asked; and towards himself and those with whom he associates good feeling, which is voluntary righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:12
verses.text: The Gnostic swears truly, but is not apt to swear, having rarely recourse to an oath, just as we have said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:13
verses.text: And his speaking truth on oath arises from his accord with the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:14
verses.text: This speaking truth on oath, then, is found to be the result of correctness in duties.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:15
verses.text: Where, then, is the necessity for an oath to him who lives in accordance with the extreme of truth? He, then, that does not even swear will be far from perjuring himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:16
verses.text: And he who does not transgress in what is ratified by compacts, will never swear; since the ratification of the violation and of the fulfilment is by actions; as certainly lying and perjury in affirming and swearing are contrary to duty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:17
verses.text: But he who lives justly, transgressing in none of his duties, when the judgment of truth is scrutinized, swears truth by his acts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:18
verses.text: Accordingly, testimony by the tongue is in his case superfluous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:19
verses.text: Therefore, persuaded always that God is everywhere, and fearing not to speak the truth, and knowing that it is unworthy of him to lie, he is satisfied with the divine consciousness and his own alone And so he lies not, nor does aught contrary to his compacts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 8:20
verses.text: And so he swears not even when asked for his oath; nor does he  ever deny, so as to speak falsehood, though he should die by tortures.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—Those Who Teach Others, Ought to Excel in Virtues.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:2
verses.text: The gnostic dignity is augmented and increased by him who has undertaken the first place in the teaching of others, and received the dispensation by word and deed of the greatest good on earth, by which he mediates contact and fellowship with the Divinity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:3
verses.text: And as those who worship terrestrial things pray to them as if they heard, confirming compacts before them; so, in men who are living images, the true majesty of the Word is received by the trustworthy teacher; and the beneficence exerted towards them is carried up to the Lord, after whose image he who is a true man by instruction creates and harmonizes, renewing to salvation the man who receives instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:4
verses.text: For as the Greeks called steel Ares, and wine Dionysus, on account of a certain relation; so the Gnostic considering the benefit of his neighbours as his own salvation, may be called a living image of the Lord, not as respects the peculiarity of form, but the symbol of power and similarity of preaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:5
verses.text: Whatever, therefore, he has in his mind, he bears on his tongue, to those who are worthy to hear, speaking as well as living from assent and inclination.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:6
verses.text: For he both thinks and speaks the truth; unless at any time, medicinally, as a physician for the safety of the sick, he may deceive or tell an untruth, according to the Sophists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:7
verses.text: To illustrate: the noble apostle circumcised Timothy, though loudly declaring and writing that circumcision made with hands profits nothing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:8
verses.text: But that he might not, by dragging all at once away from the law to the circumcision of the heart through faith those of the Hebrews who were reluctant listeners, compel them to break away from the synagogue, he, "accommodating himself to the Jews, became a Jew that he might gain all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:9
verses.text: He, then, who submits to accommodate himself merely for the benefit of his neighbours, for the salvation of those for whose sake he accommodates himself, not partaking in any dissimulation through the peril impending over the just from those who envy them, such an one by no means acts with compulsion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:10
verses.text: But for the benefit of his neighbours alone, he will do things which would not have been done by him primarily, if he did not do them on their account.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:11
verses.text: Such an one gives himself for the Church, for the disciples whom he has begotten in faith; for an example to those who are capable of receiving the supreme economy of the philanthropic and God-loving Instructor, for confirmation of the truth of his words, for the exercise of love to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:12
verses.text: Such an one is unenslaved by fear, true in word, enduring in labour, never willing to lie by uttered word, and in it always securing sinlessness; since falsehood, being spoken with a certain deceit, is not an inert word, but operates to mischief.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:13
verses.text: On every hand, then, the Gnostic alone testifies to the truth in deed and word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:14
verses.text: For he always does rightly in all things, both in word and action, and in thought itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:15
verses.text: Such, then, to speak cursorily, is the piety of the Christian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:16
verses.text: If, then, he does these things according to duty and right reason, he does them piously and justly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:17
verses.text: And if such be the case, the Gnostic alone is really both pious, and just, and God-fearing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:18
verses.text: The Christian is not impious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:19
verses.text: For this was the point incumbent on us to demonstrate to the philosophers; so that he will never in any way do aught bad or base (which is unjust).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 9:20
verses.text: Consequently, therefore, he is not impious; but he alone fears God, holily and dutifully worshipping the true God, the universal Ruler, and King, and Sovereign, with the true piety.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—Steps to Perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:2
verses.text: For knowledge (gnosis), to speak generally, a perfecting of man as man, is consummated by acquaintance with divine things, in character, life, and word, accordant and conformable to itself and to the divine Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:3
verses.text: For by it faith is perfected, inasmuch as it is solely by it that the believer becomes perfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:4
verses.text: Faith is an internal good, and without searching for God, confesses His existence, and glorifies Him as existent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:5
verses.text: Whence by starting from this faith, and being developed by it, through the grace of God, the knowledge respecting Him is to be acquired as far as possible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:6
verses.text: Now we assert that knowledge (gnosis) differs from the wisdom (σοφία), which is the result of teaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:7
verses.text: For as far as anything is knowledge, so far is it certainly wisdom; but in as far as aught is wisdom, it is not certainly knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:8
verses.text: For the term wisdom appears only in the knowledge of the uttered word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:9
verses.text: But it is not doubting in reference to God, but believing, that is the foundation of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:10
verses.text: But Christ is both the foundation and the superstructure, by whom are both the beginning and the ends.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:11
verses.text: And the extreme points, the beginning and the end—I mean faith and love—are not taught.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:12
verses.text: But knowledge, conveyed from  communication through the grace of God as a deposit, is entrusted to those who show themselves worthy of it; and from it the worth of love beams forth from light to light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:13
verses.text: For it is said, "To him that hath shall be given:" to faith, knowledge; and to knowledge, love; and to love, the inheritance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:14
verses.text: And this takes place, whenever one hangs on the Lord by faith, by knowledge, by love, and ascends along with Him to where the God and guard of our faith and love is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:15
verses.text: Whence at last (on account of the necessity for very great preparation and previous training in order both to hear what is said, and for the composure of life, and for advancing intelligently to a point beyond the righteousness of the law) it is that knowledge is committed to those fit and selected for it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:16
verses.text: It leads us to the endless and perfect end, teaching us beforehand the future life that we shall lead, according to God, and with gods; after we are freed from all punishment and penalty which we undergo, in consequence of our sins, for salutary discipline.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:17
verses.text: After which redemption the reward and the honours are assigned to those who have become perfect; when they have got done with purification, and ceased from all service, though it be holy service, and among saints.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:18
verses.text: Then become pure in heart, and near to the Lord, there awaits them restoration to everlasting contemplation; and they are called by the appellation of gods, being destined to sit on thrones with the other gods that have been first put in their places by the Saviour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:19
verses.text: Knowledge is therefore quick in purifying, and fit for that acceptable transformation to the better.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:20
verses.text: Whence also with ease it removes the soul to what is akin to the soul, divine and holy, and by its own light conveys man through the mystic stages of advancement; till it restores the pure in heart to the crowning place of rest; teaching to gaze on God, face to face, with knowledge and comprehension.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:21
verses.text: For in this consists the perfection of the gnostic soul, in its being with the Lord, where it is in immediate subjection to Him, after rising above all purification and service.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:22
verses.text: Faith is then, so to speak, a comprehensive knowledge of the essentials; and knowledge is the strong and sure demonstration of what is received by faith, built upon faith by the Lord's teaching, conveying the soul on to infallibility, science, and comprehension.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:23
verses.text: And, in my view, the first saving change is that from heathenism to faith, as I said before; and the second, that from faith to knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:24
verses.text: And the latter terminating in love, thereafter gives the loving to the loved, that which knows to that which is known.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:25
verses.text: And, perchance, such an one has already attained the condition of "being equal to the angels".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:26
verses.text: Accordingly, after the highest excellence in the flesh, changing always duly to the better, he urges his flight to the ancestral hall, through the holy septenniad of heavenly abodes to the Lord's own mansion; to be a light, steady, and continuing eternally, entirely and in every part immutable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:27
verses.text: The first mode of the Lord's operation mentioned by us is an exhibition of the recompense resulting from piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:28
verses.text: Of the very great number of testimonies that there are, I shall adduce one, thus summarily expressed by the prophet David: "Who shall ascend to the hill of the Lord, or who shall stand in His holy place? He who is guiltless in his hands, and pure in his heart; who hath not lifted up his soul to vanity, or sworn deceitfully to his neighbour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:29
verses.text: He shall receive blessing from the Lord, and mercy from God his Saviour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:30
verses.text: This is the generation of them that seek the Lord, that seek the face of the God of Jacob".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:31
verses.text: The prophet has, in my opinion, concisely indicated the Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:32
verses.text: David, as appears, has cursorily demonstrated the Saviour to be God, by calling Him "the face of the God of Jacob," who preached and taught concerning the Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:33
verses.text: Wherefore also the apostle designates as "the express image (χαρακτῆρα) of the glory of the Father" the Son, who taught the truth respecting God, and expressed the fact that the Almighty is the one and only God and Father, "whom no man knoweth but the Son, and he to whom the Son shall reveal Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:34
verses.text: That God is one is intimated by those "who seek the face of the God of Jacob;" whom being the only God, our Saviour and God characterizes as the Good Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:35
verses.text: And "the generation of those that seek Him" is the elect race, devoted to inquiry after knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:36
verses.text: Wherefore also the apostle says, "I shall profit you nothing, unless I speak to you, either by revelation, or by knowledge, or by prophecy, or by doctrine".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:37
verses.text: Although even by those who are not Gnostics some things are done rightly, yet not according to reason; as in the case of fortitude.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:38
verses.text: For some who are naturally high-spirited, and have afterwards without reason fostered this disposition, rush to many things, and act like brave men, so as sometimes to succeed in achieving the same things; just as endurance is easy for mechanics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:39
verses.text: But it is not from the same cause, or with the same object; not were they to give their whole body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:40
verses.text: "For they have not love," according to the apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:41
verses.text: All the action, then, of a man possessed of knowledge is right action; and that done by a man not possessed of knowledge is wrong action, though he observe a plan; since it is not from reflection that he acts bravely, nor does he direct his action in those things which proceed from virtue to virtue, to any useful purpose.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:42
verses.text: The same holds also with the other virtues.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:43
verses.text: So too the analogy is preserved in religion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:44
verses.text: Our Gnostic, then, not only is such in reference to holiness; but corresponding to the piety of knowledge are the commands respecting the rest of the conduct of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 10:45
verses.text: For it is our purpose at present to describe the life of the Gnostic, not to present the system of dogmas, which we shall afterwards explain at the fitting time, preserving the order of topics.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—Description of the Gnostic's Life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:2
verses.text: Respecting the universe, he conceives truly and grandly in virtue of his reception of divine teaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:3
verses.text: Beginning, then, with admiration of the Creation, and affording of himself a proof of his capability for receiving knowledge, he becomes a ready pupil of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:4
verses.text: Directly on hearing of God and Providence, he believed in consequence of the admiration he entertained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:5
verses.text: Through the power of impulse thence derived he devotes his energies in every way to learning, doing all those things by means of which he shall be able to acquire the knowledge of what he desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:6
verses.text: And desire blended with inquiry arises as faith advances.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:7
verses.text: And this is to become worthy of speculation, of such a character, and such importance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:8
verses.text: So shall the Gnostic taste of the will of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:9
verses.text: For it is not his ears, but his soul, that he yields up to the things signified by what is spoken.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:10
verses.text: Accordingly, apprehending essences and things through the words, he brings his soul, as is fit, to what is essential; apprehending (e.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:11
verses.text: g.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:12
verses.text: ) in the peculiar way in which they are spoken to the Gnostic, the commands, "Do not commit adultery," "Do not kill;" and not as they are understood by other people.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:13
verses.text: Training himself, then, in scientific speculation, he proceeds to exercise himself in larger generalizations and grander propositions; knowing right well that "He that teacheth man knowledge," according to the prophet, is the Lord, the Lord acting by man's mouth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:14
verses.text: So also He assumed flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:15
verses.text: As is right, then, he never prefers the pleasant to the useful; not even if a beautiful woman were to entice him, when overtaken by circumstances, by wantonly urging him: since Joseph's master's wife was not able to seduce him from his stedfastness; but as she violently held his coat, divested himself of it,—becoming bare of sin, but clothed with seemliness of character.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:16
verses.text: For if the eyes of the master—the Egyptian, I mean—saw not Joseph, yet those of the Almighty looked on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:17
verses.text: For we hear the voice, and see the bodily forms; but God scrutinizes the thing itself, from which the speaking and the looking proceed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:18
verses.text: Consequently, therefore, though disease, and accident, and what is most terrible of all, death, come upon the Gnostic, he remains inflexible in soul,—knowing that all such things are a necessity of creation, and that, also by the power of God, they become the medicine of salvation, benefiting by discipline those who are difficult to reform; allotted according to desert, by Providence, which is truly good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:19
verses.text: Using the creatures, then, when the Word prescribes, and to the extent it prescribes, in the exercise of thankfulness to the Creator, he becomes master of the enjoyment of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:20
verses.text: He never cherishes resentment or harbours a grudge against any one, though deserving of hatred for his conduct.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:21
verses.text: For he worships the Maker, and loves him, who shares life, pitying and praying for him on account of his ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:22
verses.text: He indeed partakes of the affections of the body, to which, susceptible as it is of suffering by nature, he is bound.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:23
verses.text: But in sensation he is not the primary subject of it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:24
verses.text: Accordingly, then, in involuntary circumstances, by withdrawing himself from troubles to the things which really belong to him, he is not carried away with what is foreign to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:25
verses.text: And it is only to things that are necessary for him that he accommodates himself, in so far as the soul is preserved unharmed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:26
verses.text: For it is not in supposition or seeming that he wishes to be faithful; but in knowledge and truth, that is, in sure deed and effectual word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:27
verses.text: Wherefore he not only praises what is noble, but endeavours himself to be noble; changing by love from a good and faithful servant into a friend, through the perfection of habit, which he has acquired in purity from true instruction and great discipline.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:28
verses.text: Striving, then, to attain to the summit of knowledge (gnosis); decorous in character; composed in mien; possessing all those advantages which belong to the true Gnostic; fixing his eye on fair models, on the many patriarchs who have lived rightly, and on very many prophets and angels reckoned without number, and above all, on the Lord, who taught and showed it to be possible for him to attain that highest life of all,—he therefore loves not all the good things of the world, which are within  his grasp, that he may not remain on the ground, but the things hoped for, or rather already known, being hoped for so as to be apprehended.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:29
verses.text: So then he undergoes toils, and trials, and afflictions, not as those among the philosophers who are endowed with manliness, in the hope of present troubles ceasing, and of sharing again in what is pleasant; but knowledge has inspired him with the firmest persuasion of receiving the hopes of the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:30
verses.text: Wherefore he contemns not alone the pains of this world, but all its pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:31
verses.text: They say, accordingly, that the blessed Peter, on seeing his wife led to death, rejoiced on account of her call and conveyance home, and called very encouragingly and comfortingly, addressing her by name, "Remember thou the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:32
verses.text: Such was the marriage of the blessed and their perfect disposition towards those dearest to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:33
verses.text: Thus also the apostle says, "that he who marries should be as though he married not," and deem his marriage free of inordinate affection, and inseparable from love to the Lord; to which the true husband exhorted his wife to cling on her departure out of this life to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:34
verses.text: Was not then faith in the hope after death conspicuous in the case of those who gave thanks to God even in the very extremities of their punishments? For firm, in my opinion, was the faith they possessed, which was followed by works of faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:35
verses.text: In all circumstances, then, is the soul of the Gnostic strong, in a condition of extreme health and strength, like the body of an athlete.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:36
verses.text: For he is prudent in human affairs, in judging what ought to be done by the just man; having obtained the principles from God from above, and having acquired, in order to the divine resemblance, moderation in bodily pains and pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:37
verses.text: And he struggles against fears boldly, trusting in God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:38
verses.text: Certainly, then, the gnostic soul, adorned with perfect virtue, is the earthly image of the divine power; its development being the joint result of nature, of training, of reason, all together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:39
verses.text: This beauty of the soul becomes a temple of the Holy Spirit, when it acquires a disposition in the whole of life corresponding to the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:40
verses.text: Such an one consequently withstands all fear of everything terrible, not only of death, but also poverty and disease, and ignominy, and things akin to these; being unconquered by pleasure, and lord over irrational desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:41
verses.text: For he well knows what is and what is not to be done; being perfectly aware what things are really to be dreaded, and what not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:42
verses.text: Whence he bears intelligently what the Word intimates to him to be requisite and necessary; intelligently discriminating what is really safe (that is, good), from what appears so; and things to be dreaded from what seems so, such as death, disease, and poverty; which are rather so in opinion than in truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:43
verses.text: This is the really good man, who is without passions; having, through the habit or disposition of the soul endued with virtue, transcended the whole life of passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:44
verses.text: He has everything dependent on himself for the attainment of the end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:45
verses.text: For those accidents which are called terrible are not formidable to the good man, because they are not evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:46
verses.text: And those which are really to be dreaded are foreign to the gnostic Christian, being diametrically opposed to what is good, because evil; and it is impossible for contraries to meet in the same person at the same time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:47
verses.text: He, then, who faultlessly acts the drama of life which God has given him to play, knows both what is to be done and what is to be endured.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:48
verses.text: Is it not then from ignorance of what is and what is not to be dreaded that cowardice arises? Consequently the only man of courage is the Gnostic, who knows both present and future good things; along with these, knowing, as I have said, also the things which are in reality not to be dreaded.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:49
verses.text: Because, knowing vice alone to be hateful, and destructive of what contributes to knowledge, protected by the armour of the Lord, he makes war against it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:50
verses.text: For if anything is caused through folly, and the operation or rather co-operation of the devil, this thing is not straightway the devil or folly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:51
verses.text: For no action is wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:52
verses.text: For wisdom is a habit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:53
verses.text: And no action is a habit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:54
verses.text: The action, then, that arises from ignorance, is not already ignorance, but an evil through ignorance, but not ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:55
verses.text: For neither perturbations of mind nor sins are vices, though proceeding from vice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:56
verses.text: No one, then, who is irrationally brave is a Gnostic; since one might call children brave, who, through ignorance of what is to be dreaded, undergo things that are frightful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:57
verses.text: So they touch fire even.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:58
verses.text: And the wild beasts that rush close on the points of spears, having a brute courage, might be called valiant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:59
verses.text: And such people might perhaps call jugglers valiant, who tumble on swords with a certain dexterity, practising a mischievous art for sorry gain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:60
verses.text: But he who is truly brave, with the peril arising from the bad feeling of the multitude before his eyes, courageously awaits whatever comes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:61
verses.text: In this way he is distinguished  from others that are called martyrs, inasmuch as some furnish occasions for themselves, and rush into the heart of dangers, I know not how (for it is right to use mild language); while they, in accordance with right reason, protect themselves; then, on God really calling them, promptly surrender themselves, and confirm the call, from being conscious of no precipitancy, and present the man to be proved in the exercise of true rational fortitude.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:62
verses.text: Neither, then, enduring lesser dangers from fear of greater, like other people, nor dreading censure at the hands of their equals, and those of like sentiments, do they continue in the confession of their calling; but from love to God they willingly obey the call, with no other aim in view than pleasing God, and not for the sake of the reward of their toils.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:63
verses.text: For some suffer from love of glory, and others from fear of some other sharper punishment, and others for the sake of pleasures and delights after death, being children in faith; blessed indeed, but not yet become men in love to God, as the Gnostic is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:64
verses.text: For there are, as in the gymnastic contests, so also in the Church, crowns for men and for children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:65
verses.text: But love is to be chosen for itself, and for nothing else.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:66
verses.text: Therefore in the Gnostic, along with knowledge, the perfection of fortitude is developed from the discipline of life, he having always studied to acquire mastery over the passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:67
verses.text: Accordingly, love makes its own athlete fearless and dauntless, and confident in the Lord, anointing and training him; as righteousness secures for him truthfulness in his whole life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:68
verses.text: For it was a compendium of righteousness to say, "Let your yea be yea; and your nay, nay".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:69
verses.text: And the same holds with self-control.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:70
verses.text: For it is neither for love of honour, as the athletes for the sake of crowns and fame; nor on the other hand, for love of money, as some pretend to exercise self-control, pursuing what is good with terrible suffering.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:71
verses.text: Nor is it from love of the body for the sake of health.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:72
verses.text: Nor any more is any man who is temperate from rusticity, who has not tasted pleasures, truly a man of self-control.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:73
verses.text: Certainly those who have led a laborious life, on tasting pleasures, forthwith break down the inflexibility of temperance into pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:74
verses.text: Such are they who are restrained by law and fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:75
verses.text: For on finding a favourable opportunity they defraud the law, by giving what is good the slip.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:76
verses.text: But self-control, desirable for its own sake, perfected through knowledge, abiding ever, makes the man lord and master of himself; so that the Gnostic is temperate and passionless, incapable of being dissolved by pleasures and pains, as they say adamant is by fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:77
verses.text: The cause of these, then, is love, of all science the most sacred and most sovereign.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:78
verses.text: For by the service of what is best and most exalted, which is characterized by unity, it renders the Gnostic at once friend and son, having in truth grown "a perfect man, up to the measure of full stature".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:79
verses.text: Further, agreement in the same thing is consent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:80
verses.text: But what is the same is one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:81
verses.text: And friendship is consummated in likeness; the community lying in oneness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:82
verses.text: The Gnostic, consequently, in virtue of being a lover of the one true God, is the really perfect man and friend of God, and is placed in the rank of son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:83
verses.text: For these are names of nobility and knowledge, and perfection in the contemplation of God; which crowning step of advancement the gnostic soul receives, when it has become quite pure, reckoned worthy to behold everlastingly God Almighty, "face," it is said, "to face".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 11:84
verses.text: For having become wholly spiritual, and having in the spiritual Church gone to what is of kindred nature, it abides in the rest of God.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—The True Gnostic is Beneficent, Continent, and Despises Worldly Things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:2
verses.text: Let these things, then, be so.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:3
verses.text: And such being the attitude of the Gnostic towards the body and the soul—towards his neighbours, whether it be a domestic, or a lawful enemy, or whosoever—he is found equal and like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:4
verses.text: For he does not "despise his brother," who, according to the divine law, is of the same father and mother.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:5
verses.text: Certainly he relieves the afflicted, helping him with consolations, encouragements, and the necessaries of life; giving to all that need, though not similarly, but justly, according to desert; furthermore, to him who persecutes and hates, even if he need it; caring little for those who say to him that he has given out of fear, if it is not out of fear that he does so, but to give help.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:6
verses.text: For how much more are those, who towards their enemies are devoid of love of money, and are haters of evil, animated with love to those who belong to them?  Such an one from this proceeds to the accurate knowledge of whom he ought chiefly to give to, and how much, and when, and how.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:7
verses.text: And who could with any reason become the enemy of a man who gives no cause for enmity in any way? And is it not just as in the case of God? We say that God is the adversary of no one, and the enemy of no one (for He is the Creator of all, and nothing that exists is what He wills it not to be; but we assert that the disobedient, and those who walk not according to His commandments, are enemies to Him, as being those who are hostile to His covenant).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:8
verses.text: We shall find the very same to be the case with the Gnostic, for he can never in any way become an enemy to any one; but those may be regarded enemies to him who turn to the contrary path.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:9
verses.text: In particular, the habit of liberality which prevails among us is called "righteousness;" but the power of discriminating according to desert, as to greater and less, with reference to those who am proper subjects of it, is a form of the very highest righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:10
verses.text: There are things practiced in a vulgar style by some people, such as control over pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:11
verses.text: For as, among the heathen, there are those who, from the impossibility of obtaining what one sees, and from fear of men, and also for the sake of greater pleasures, abstain from the delights that are before them; so also, in the case of faith, some practice self-restraint, either out of regard to the promise or from fear of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:12
verses.text: Well, such self-restraint is the basis of knowledge, and an approach to something better, and an effort after perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:13
verses.text: For "the fear of the Lord," it is said, "is the beginning of wisdom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:14
verses.text: But the perfect man, out of love, "beareth all things, endureth all things," "as not pleasing man, but God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:15
verses.text: Although praise follows him as a consequence, it is not for his own advantage, but for the imitation and benefit of those who praise him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:16
verses.text: According to another view, it is not he who merely controls his passions that is called a continent man, but he who has also achieved the mastery over good things, and has acquired surely the great accomplishments of science, from which he produces as fruits the activities of virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:17
verses.text: Thus the Gnostic is never, on the occurrence of an emergency, dislodged from the habit peculiar to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:18
verses.text: For the scientific possession of what is good is firm and unchangeable, being the knowledge of things divine and human.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:19
verses.text: Knowledge, then, never becomes ignorance nor does good change into evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:20
verses.text: Wherefore also he eats, and drinks, and marries, not as principal ends of existence, but as necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:21
verses.text: I name marriage even, if the Word prescribe, and as is suitable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:22
verses.text: For having become perfect, he has the apostles for examples; and one is not really shown to be a man in the choice of single life; but he surpasses men, who, disciplined by marriage, procreation of children, and care for the house, without pleasure or pain, in his solicitude for the house has been inseparable from God's love, and withstood all temptation arising through children, and wife, and domestics, and possessions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:23
verses.text: But he that has no family is in a great degree free of temptation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:24
verses.text: Caring, then, for himself alone, he is surpassed by him who is inferior, as far as his own personal salvation is concerned, but who is superior in the conduct of life, preserving certainly, in his care for the truth, a minute image.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:25
verses.text: But we must as much as possible subject the soul to varied preparatory exercise, that it may become susceptible to the reception of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:26
verses.text: Do you not see how wax is softened and copper purified, in order to receive the stamp applied to it? Just as death is the separation of the soul from the body, so is knowledge as it were the rational death urging the spirit away, and separating it from the passions, and leading it on to the life of well-doing, that it may then say with confidence to God, "I live as Thou wishest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:27
verses.text: For he who makes it his purpose to please men cannot please God, since the multitude choose not what is profitable, but what is pleasant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:28
verses.text: But in pleasing God, one as a consequence gets the favour of the good among men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:29
verses.text: How, then, can what relates to meat, and drink, and amorous pleasure, be agreeable to such an one? since he views with suspicion even a word that produces pleasure, and a pleasant movement and act of the mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:30
verses.text: "For no one can serve two masters, God and Mammon," it is said; meaning not simply money, but the resources arising from money bestowed on various pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:31
verses.text: In reality, it is not possible for him who magnanimously and truly knows God, to serve antagonistic pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:32
verses.text: There is one alone, then, who from the beginning was free of concupiscence—the philanthropic Lord, who for us became man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:33
verses.text: And whosoever endeavour to be assimilated to the impress given by Him, strive, from exercise, to become free of concupiscence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:34
verses.text: For he who has exercised concupiscence and then restrained himself, is like a widow who becomes again a virgin by continence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:35
verses.text: Such is the reward of knowledge, rendered to the Saviour and Teacher, which He Himself asked for,—abstinence from what is evil, activity in doing good, by which salvation is acquired.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:36
verses.text: As, then, those who have learned the arts procure their living by what they have been taught, so also is the Gnostic saved, procuring life by what he knows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:37
verses.text: For he who has not formed the wish to extirpate the passion of the soul, kills himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:38
verses.text: But, as seems, ignorance is the starvation of the soul, and knowledge its sustenance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:39
verses.text: Such are the gnostic souls, which the Gospel  likened to the consecrated virgins who wait for the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:40
verses.text: For they are virgins, in respect of their abstaining from what is evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:41
verses.text: And in respect of their waiting out of love for the Lord and kindling their light for the contemplation of things, they are wise souls, saying, "Lord, for long we have desired to receive Thee; we have lived according to what Thou hast enjoined, transgressing none of Thy commandments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:42
verses.text: Wherefore also we claim the promises.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:43
verses.text: And we pray for what is beneficial, since it is not requisite to ask of Thee what is most excellent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:44
verses.text: And we shall take everything for good; even though the exercises that meet us, which Thine arrangement brings to us for the discipline of our stedfastness, appear to be evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:45
verses.text: The Gnostic, then, from his exceeding holiness, is better prepared to fail when he asks, than to get when he does not ask.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:46
verses.text: His whole life is prayer and converse with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:47
verses.text: And if he be pure from sins, he will by all means obtain what he wishes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:48
verses.text: For God says to the righteous man, "Ask, and I will give thee; think, and I will do".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:49
verses.text: If beneficial, he will receive it at once; and if injurious, he will never ask it, and therefore he will not receive it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:50
verses.text: So it shall be as he wishes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:51
verses.text: But if one say to us, that some sinners even obtain according to their requests, we should say that this rarely takes place, by reason of the righteous goodness of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:52
verses.text: And it is granted to those who are capable of doing others good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:53
verses.text: Whence the gift is not made for the sake of him that asked it; but the divine dispensation, foreseeing that one would be saved by his means, renders the boon again righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:54
verses.text: And to those who are worthy, things which are really good are given, even without their asking.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:55
verses.text: Whenever, then, one is righteous, not from necessity or out of fear or hope, but from free choice, this is called the royal road, which the royal race travel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:56
verses.text: But the byways are slippery and precipitous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:57
verses.text: If, then, one take away fear and honour, I do not know if the illustrious among the philosophers, who use such freedom of speech, will any longer endure afflictions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:58
verses.text: Now lusts and other sins are called "briars and thorns".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:59
verses.text: Accordingly the Gnostic labours in the Lord's vineyard, planting, pruning, watering; being the divine husbandman of what is planted in faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:60
verses.text: Those, then, who have not done evil, think it right to receive the wages of ease.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:61
verses.text: But he who has done good out of free choice, demands the recompense as a good workman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:62
verses.text: He certainly shall receive double wages—both for what he has not done, and for what good he has done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:63
verses.text: Such a Gnostic is tempted by no one except with God's permission, and that for the benefit of those who are with him; and he strengthens them for faith, encouraging them by manly endurance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:64
verses.text: And assuredly it was for this end, for the establishment and confirmation of the Churches, that the blessed apostles were brought into trial and to martyrdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:65
verses.text: The Gnostic, then, hearing a voice ringing in his ear, which says, "Whom I shall strike, do thou pity," beseeches that those who hate him may repent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:66
verses.text: For the punishment of malefactors, to be consummated in the highways, is for children to behold; for there is no possibility of the Gnostic, who has from choice trained himself to be excellent and good, ever being instructed or delighted with such spectacles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:67
verses.text: And so, having become incapable of being softened by pleasures, and never falling into sins, he is not corrected by the examples of other men's sufferings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:68
verses.text: And far from being pleased with earthly pleasures and spectacles is he who has shown a noble contempt for the prospects held out in this world, although they are divine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:69
verses.text: "Not every one," therefore, "that says Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of God; but he that doeth the will of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:70
verses.text: Such is the gnostic labourer, who has the mastery of worldly desires even while still in the flesh; and who, in regard to things future and still invisible, which he knows, has a sure persuasion, so that he regards them as more present than the things within reach.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:71
verses.text: This able workman rejoices in what he knows, but is cramped on account of his being involved in the necessities of life; not yet deemed worthy of the active participation in what he knows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:72
verses.text: So he uses this life as if it belonged to another,—so far, that is, as is necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:73
verses.text: He knows also the enigmas of the fasting of those days—I mean the Fourth and the Preparation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:74
verses.text: For the one has its name from Hermes, and the other from Aphrodite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:75
