verses.text: He fasts in his life, in respect of covetousness and voluptuousness, from which all the vices grow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:76
verses.text: For we have already often above shown the three varieties of fornication, according to the apostle—love of pleasure, love of money, idolatry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:77
verses.text: He fasts, then, according to the Law, abstaining from bad deeds, and, according to the perfection of the Gospel, from evil thoughts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:78
verses.text: Temptations are applied to him, not for his purification, but, as we have said, for the good of his neighbours,  if, making trial of toils and pains, he has despised and passed them by.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:79
verses.text: The same holds of pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:80
verses.text: For it is the highest achievement for one who has had trial of it, afterwards to abstain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:81
verses.text: For what great thing is it, if a man restrains himself in what he knows not? He, in fulfilment of the precept, according to the Gospel, keeps the Lord's day, when he abandons an evil disposition, and assumes that of the Gnostic, glorifying the Lord's resurrection in himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:82
verses.text: Further, also, when he has received the comprehension of scientific speculation, he deems that he sees the Lord, directing his eyes towards things invisible, although he seems to look on what he does not wish to look on; chastising the faculty of vision, when he perceives himself pleasurably affected by the application of his eyes; since he wishes to see and hear that alone which concerns him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:83
verses.text: In the act of contemplating the souls of the brethren, he beholds the beauty of the flesh also, with the soul itself, which has become habituated to look solely upon that which is good, without carnal pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:84
verses.text: And they are really brethren; inasmuch as, by reason of their elect creation, and their oneness of character, and the nature of their deeds, they do, and think, and speak the same holy and good works, in accordance with the sentiments with which the Lord wished them as elect to be inspired.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:85
verses.text: For faith shows itself in their making choice of the same things; and knowledge, in learning and thinking the same things; and hope, in desiring the same things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:86
verses.text: And if, through the necessity of life, he spend a small portion of time about his sustenance, he thinks himself defrauded, being diverted by business.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:87
verses.text: Thus not even in dreams does he look on aught that is unsuitable to an elect man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:88
verses.text: For thoroughly a stranger and sojourner in the whole of life is every such one, who, inhabiting the city, despises the things in the city which are admired by others, and lives in the city as in a desert, so that the place may not compel him, but his mode of life show him to be just.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:89
verses.text: This Gnostic, to speak compendiously, makes up for the absence of the apostles, by the rectitude of his life, the accuracy of his knowledge, by benefiting his relations, by "removing the mountains" of his neighbours, and putting away the irregularities of their soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:90
verses.text: Although each of us is his own vineyard and labourer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:91
verses.text: He, too, while doing the most excellent things, wishes to elude the notice of men, persuading the Lord along with himself that he is living in accordance with the commandments, preferring these things from believing them to exist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:92
verses.text: "For where any one's mind is, there also is his treasure".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:93
verses.text: He impoverishes himself, in order that he may never overlook a brother who has been brought into affliction, through the perfection that is in love, especially if he know that he will bear want himself easier than his brother.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:94
verses.text: He considers, accordingly, the other's pain his own grief; and if, by contributing from his own indigence in order to do good, he suffer any hardship, he does not fret at this, but augments his beneficence still more.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:95
verses.text: For he possesses in its sincerity the faith which is exercised in reference to the affairs of life, and praises the Gospel in practice and contemplation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:96
verses.text: And, in truth, he wins his praise "not from men, but from God," by the performance of what the Lord has taught.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:97
verses.text: He, attracted by his own hope, tastes not the good things that are in the world, entertaining a noble contempt for all things here; pitying those that are chastised after death, who through punishment unwillingly make confession; having a clear conscience with reference to his departure, and being always ready, as "a stranger and pilgrim," with regard to the inheritances here; mindful only of those that are his own, and regarding all things here as not his own; not only admiring the Lord's commandments, but, so to speak, being by knowledge itself partaker of the divine will; a truly chosen intimate of the Lord and His commands in virtue of being righteous; and princely and kingly as being a Gnostic; despising all the gold on earth and under the earth, and dominion from shore to shore of ocean, so that he may cling to the sole service of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:98
verses.text: Wherefore also, in eating, and drinking, and marrying (if the Word enjoin), and even in seeing dreams, he does and thinks what is holy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:99
verses.text: So is he always pure for prayer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:100
verses.text: He also prays in the society of angels, as being already of angelic rank, and he is never out of their holy keeping; and though he pray alone, he has the choir of the saints standing with him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:101
verses.text: He recognises a twofold element in faith, both the activity of him who believes, and the  excellence of that which is believed according to its worth; since also righteousness is twofold, that which is out of love, and that from fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:102
verses.text: Accordingly it is said, "The fear of the Lord is pure, remaining for ever and ever".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:103
verses.text: For those that from fear turn to faith and righteousness, remain for ever.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:104
verses.text: Now fear works abstinence from what is evil; but love exhorts to the doing of good, by building up to the point of spontaneousness; that one may hear from the Lord, "I call you no longer servants, but friends," and may now with confidence apply himself to prayer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:105
verses.text: And the form of his prayer is thanksgiving for the past, for the present, and for the future as already through faith present.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:106
verses.text: This is preceded by the reception of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:107
verses.text: And he asks to live the allotted life in the flesh as a Gnostic, as free from the flesh, and to attain to the best things, and flee from the worse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:108
verses.text: He asks, too, relief in those things in which we have sinned, and conversion to the acknowledgment of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:109
verses.text: He follows, on his departure, Him who calls, as quickly, so to speak, as He who goes before calls, hasting by reason of a good conscience to give thanks; and having got there with Christ shows himself worthy, through his purity, to possess, by a process of blending, the power of God communicated by Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:110
verses.text: For he does not wish to be warm by participation in heat, or luminous by participation in flame, but to be wholly light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:111
verses.text: He knows accurately the declaration, "Unless ye hate father and mother, and besides your own life, and unless ye bear the sign of the cross".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:112
verses.text: For he hates the inordinate affections of the flesh, which possess the powerful spell of pleasure; and entertains a noble contempt for all that belongs to the creation and nutriment of the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:113
verses.text: He also withstands the corporeal soul, putting a bridle-bit on the restive irrational spirit: "For the flesh lusteth against the Spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:114
verses.text: And "to bear the sign of the cross" is to bear about death, by taking farewell of all things while still alive; since there is not equal love in "having sown the flesh," and in having formed the soul for knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:115
verses.text: He having acquired the habit of doing good, exercises beneficence well, quicker than speaking; praying that he may get a share in the sins of his brethren, in order to confession and conversion on the part of his kindred; and eager to give a share to those dearest to him of his own good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:116
verses.text: And so these are to him, friends.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:117
verses.text: Promoting, then, the growth of the seeds deposited in him, according to the husbandry enjoined by the Lord, he continues free of sin, and becomes continent, and lives in spirit with those who are like him, among the choirs of the saints, though still detained on earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:118
verses.text: He, all day and night, speaking and doing the Lord's commands, rejoices exceedingly, not only on rising in the morning and at noon, but also when walking about, when asleep, when dressing and undressing; and he teaches his son, if he has a son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:119
verses.text: He is inseparable from the commandment and from hope, and is ever giving thanks to God, like the living creatures figuratively spoken of by Esaias, and submissive in every trial, he says, "The Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:120
verses.text: For such also was Job; who after the spoiling of his effects, along with the health of his body, resigned all through love to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:121
verses.text: For "he was," it is said, "just, holy, and kept apart from all wickedness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:122
verses.text: Now the word "holy" points out all duties toward God, and the entire course of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:123
verses.text: Knowing which, he was a Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:124
verses.text: For we must neither cling too much to such things, even if they are good, seeing they are human, nor on the other hand detest them, if they are bad; but we must be above both good and bad, trampling the latter under foot, and passing on the former to those who need them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 12:125
verses.text: But the Gnostic is cautious in accommodation, lest he be not perceived, or lest the accommodation become disposition.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—Description of the Gnostic Continued.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:2
verses.text: He never remembers those who have sinned against him, but forgives them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:3
verses.text: Wherefore also he righteously prays, saying, "Forgive us; for we also forgive".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:4
verses.text: For this also is one of the things which God wishes, to covet nothing, to hate no one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:5
verses.text: For all men are the work of one will.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:6
verses.text: And is it not the Saviour, who wishes the Gnostic to be perfect as "the heavenly Father," that is, Himself, who says, "Come, ye children, hear from me the fear of the Lord?" He wishes him no longer to stand in need of help by angels, but to receive it from Himself, having become worthy, and to have protection from Himself by obedience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:7
verses.text: Such an one demands from the Lord, and does not merely ask.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:8
verses.text: And in the case of his brethren in want, the Gnostic will not ask himself for abundance of wealth to bestow, but will pray that the supply of what they need may be furnished to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:9
verses.text: For so the Gnostic gives his prayer to those who are in need, and by his  prayer they are supplied, without his knowledge, and without vanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:10
verses.text: Penury and disease, and such trials, are often sent for admonition, for the correction of the past, and for care for the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:11
verses.text: Such an one prays for relief from them, in virtue of possessing the prerogative of knowledge, not out of vainglory; but from the very fact of his being a Gnostic, he works beneficence, having become the instrument of the goodness of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:12
verses.text: They say in the traditions that Matthew the apostle constantly said, that "if the neighbour of an elect man sin, the elect man has sinned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:13
verses.text: For had he conducted himself as the Word prescribes, his neighbour also would have been filled with such reverence for the life he led as not to sin".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:14
verses.text: What, then, shall we say of the Gnostic himself? "Know ye not," says the apostle, "that ye are the temple of God?" The Gnostic is consequently divine, and already holy, God-bearing, and God-borne.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:15
verses.text: Now the Scripture, showing that sinning is foreign to him, sells those who have fallen away to strangers, saying, "Look not on a strange woman, to lust," plainly pronounces sin foreign and contrary to the nature of the temple of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:16
verses.text: Now the temple is great, as the Church, and it is small, as the man who preserves the seed of Abraham.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:17
verses.text: He, therefore, who has God resting in him will not desire aught else.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:18
verses.text: At once leaving all hindrances, and despising all matter which distracts him, he cleaves the heaven by knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:19
verses.text: And passing through the spiritual Essences, and all rule and authority, he touches the highest thrones, hasting to that alone for the sake of which alone he knew.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:20
verses.text: Mixing, then, "the serpent with the dove," he lives at once perfectly and with a good conscience, mingling faith with hope, in order to the expectation of the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:21
verses.text: For he is conscious of the boon he has received, having become worthy of obtaining it; and is translated from slavery to adoption, as the consequence of knowledge; knowing God, or rather known of Him, for the end, he puts forth energies corresponding to the worth of grace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:22
verses.text: For works follow knowledge, as the shadow the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:23
verses.text: Rightly, then, he is not disturbed by anything which happens; nor does he suspect those things, which, through divine arrangement, take place for good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:24
verses.text: Nor is he ashamed to die, having a good conscience, and being fit to be seen by the Powers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:25
verses.text: Cleansed, so to speak, from all the stains of the soul, he knows right well that it will be better with him after his departure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:26
verses.text: Whence he never prefers pleasure and profit to the divine arrangement, since he trains himself by the commands, that in all things he may be well pleasing to the Lord, and praiseworthy in the sight of the world, since all things depend on the one Sovereign God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:27
verses.text: The Son of God, it is said, came to His own, and His own received Him not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:28
verses.text: Wherefore also in the use of the things of the world he not only gives thanks and praises the creation, but also, while using them as is right, is praised; since the end he has in view terminates in contemplation by gnostic activity in accordance with the commandments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:29
verses.text: Thence now, by knowledge collecting materials to be the food of contemplation, having embraced nobly the magnitude of knowledge, he advances to the holy recompense of translation hence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:30
verses.text: For he has heard the Psalm which says: "Encircle Zion, and encompass it, tell upon its towers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:31
verses.text: For it intimates, I think, those who have sublimely embraced the Word, so as to become lofty towers, and to stand firmly in faith and knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:32
verses.text: Let these statements concerning the Gnostic, containing the germs of the matter in as brief terms as possible, be made to the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 13:33
verses.text: But let it be known that if the mere believer do rightly one or a second of these things, yet he will not do so in all nor with the highest knowledge, like the Gnostic.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 14—Description of the Gnostic Furnished by an Exposition of  Cor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:2
verses.text: 6 - , Etc.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:3
verses.text: Now, of what I may call the passionlessness which we attribute to the Gnostic (in which the perfection of the believer, "advancing by love, comes to a perfect man, to the measure of full stature," by being assimilated to God, and by becoming truly angelic), many other testimonies from the Scripture, occur to me to adduce.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:4
verses.text: But I think it better, on account of the length of the discourse, that such an honour should be devolved on those who wish to take pains, and leave it to them to elaborate the dogmas by the selection of Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:5
verses.text: One passage, accordingly, I shall in the briefest terms advert to, so as not to leave the topic unexplained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:6
verses.text: For in the first Epistle to the Corinthians the divine apostle says: "Dare any of you, having a matter against the other, go to law before the unrighteous, and not before the saints? Know ye not that the saints shall judge the world?" and so on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:7
verses.text: The section being very long, we shall exhibit the meaning of the apostle's utterance by employing  such of the apostolic expressions as are most pertinent, and in the briefest language, and in a sort of cursory way, interpreting the discourse in which he describes the perfection of the Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:8
verses.text: For he does not merely instance the Gnostic as characterized by suffering wrong rather than do wrong; but he teaches that he is not mindful of injuries, and does not allow him even to pray against the man who has done him wrong.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:9
verses.text: For he knows that the Lord expressly enjoined "to pray for enemies".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:10
verses.text: To say, then, that the man who has been injured goes to law before the unrighteous, is nothing else than to say that he shows a wish to retaliate, and a desire to injure the second in return, which is also to do wrong likewise himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:11
verses.text: And his saying, that he wishes "some to go to law before the saints," points out those who ask by prayer that those who have done wrong should suffer retaliation for their injustice, and intimates that the second are better than the former; but they are not yet obedient, if they do not, having become entirely free of resentment, pray even for their enemies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:12
verses.text: It is well, then, for them to receive right dispositions from repentance, which results in faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:13
verses.text: For if the truth seems to get enemies who entertain bad feeling, yet it is not hostile to any one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:14
verses.text: "For God makes His sun to shine on the just and on the unjust," and sent the Lord Himself to the just and the unjust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:15
verses.text: And he that earnestly strives to be assimilated to God, in the exercise of great absence of resentment, forgives seventy times seven times, as it were all his life through, and in all his course in this world (that being indicated by the enumeration of sevens) shows clemency to each and any one; if any during the whole time of his life in the flesh do the Gnostic wrong.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:16
verses.text: For he not only deems it right that the good man should resign his property alone to others, being of the number of those who have done him wrong; but also wishes that the righteous man should ask of those judges forgiveness for the offences of those who have done him wrong.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:17
verses.text: And with reason, if indeed it is only in that which is external and concerns the body, though it go to the extent of death even, that those who attempt to wrong him take advantage of him; none of which truly belong to the Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:18
verses.text: And how shall one "judge" the apostate "angels," who has become himself an apostate from that forgetfulness of injuries, which is according to the Gospel? "Why do ye not rather suffer wrong?" he says; "why are ye not rather defrauded? Yea, ye do wrong and defraud," manifestly by praying against those who transgress in ignorance, and deprive of the philanthropy and goodness of God, as far as in you lies, those against whom you pray, "and these your brethren,"—not meaning those in the faith only, but also the proselytes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:19
verses.text: For whether he who now is hostile shall afterwards believe, we know not as yet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:20
verses.text: From which the conclusion follows clearly, if all are not yet brethren to us, they ought to be regarded in that light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:21
verses.text: And now it is only the man of knowledge who recognises all men to be the work of one God, and invested with one image in one nature, although some may be more turbid than others; and in the creatures he recognises the operation, by which again he adores the will of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:22
verses.text: "Know ye not that the unrighteous shall not inherit the kingdom of God?" He acts unrighteously who retaliates, whether by deed or word, or by the conception of a wish, which, after the training of the Law, the Gospel rejects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:23
verses.text: "And such were some of you"—such manifestly as those still are whom you do not forgive; "but ye are washed," not simply as the rest, but with knowledge; ye have cast off the passions of the soul, in order to become assimilated, as far as possible, to the goodness of God's providence by long-suffering, and by forgiveness "towards the just and the unjust," casting on them the gleam of benignity in word and deeds, as the sun.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:24
verses.text: The Gnostic will achieve this either by greatness of mind, or by imitation of what is better.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:25
verses.text: And that is a third cause.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:26
verses.text: "Forgive, and it shall be forgiven you;" the commandment, as it were, compelling to salvation through superabundance of goodness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:27
verses.text: "But ye are sanctified".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:28
verses.text: For he who has come to this state is in a condition to be holy, falling into none of the passions in any way, but as it were already disembodied and already grown holy without this earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:29
verses.text: "Wherefore," he says, "ye are justified in the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:30
verses.text: Ye are made, so to speak, by Him to be righteous as He is, and are blended as far as possible with the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:31
verses.text: For "are not all things lawful to me? yet I will not be brought under the power of any," so as to do, or think, or speak aught contrary to the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:32
verses.text: "Meats for the belly, and the belly for meats, which God shall destroy,"—that is, such as think and live as if they were made for eating, and do not eat that they may live as a consequence, and apply to knowledge as the primary end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:33
verses.text: And does he not say that these are, as it were, the fleshy parts of the holy body? As a  body, the Church of the Lord, the spiritual and holy choir, is symbolized.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:34
verses.text: Whence those, who are merely called, but do not live in accordance with the word, are the fleshy parts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:35
verses.text: "Now" this spiritual "body," the holy Church, "is not for fornication".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:36
verses.text: Nor are those things which belong to heathen life to be adopted by apostasy from the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:37
verses.text: For he who conducts himself heathenishly in the Church, whether in deed, or word, or even in thought, commits fornication with reference to the Church and his own body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:38
verses.text: He who in this way "is joined to the harlot," that is, to conduct contrary to the Covenant becomes another "body," not holy, "and one flesh," and has a heathenish life and another hope.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:39
verses.text: "But he that is joined to the Lord in spirit" becomes a spiritual body by a different kind of conjunction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:40
verses.text: Such an one is wholly a son, an holy man, passionless, gnostic, perfect, formed by the teaching of the Lord; in order that in deed, in word, and in spirit itself, being brought close to the Lord, he may receive the mansion that is due to him who has reached manhood thus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:41
verses.text: Let the specimen suffice to those who have ears.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:42
verses.text: For it is not required to unfold the mystery, but only to indicate what is sufficient for those who are partakers in knowledge to bring it to mind; who also will comprehend how it was said by the Lord, "Be ye perfect as your father, perfectly," by forgiving sins, and forgetting injuries, and living in the habit of passionlessness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:43
verses.text: For as we call a physician perfect, and a philosopher perfect, so also, in my view, do we call a Gnostic perfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:44
verses.text: But not one of those points, although of the greatest importance, is assumed in order to the likeness of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:45
verses.text: For we do not say, as the Stoics do most impiously, that virtue in man and God is the same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:46
verses.text: Ought we not then to be perfect, as the Father wills? For it is utterly impossible for any one to become perfect as God is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:47
verses.text: Now the Father wishes us to be perfect by living blamelessly, according to the obedience of the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 14:48
verses.text: If, then, the statement being elliptical, we understand what is wanting, in order to complete the section for those who are incapable of understanding what is left out, we shall both know the will of God, and shall walk at once piously and magnanimously, as befits the dignity of the commandment.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 15—The Objection to Join the Church on Account of the Diversity of Heresies Answered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:2
verses.text: Since it comes next to reply to the objections alleged against us by Greeks and Jews; and since, in some of the questions previously discussed, the sects also who adhere to other teaching give, their help, it will be well first to clear away the obstacles before us, and then, prepared thus for the solution of the difficulties, to advance to the succeeding Miscellany.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:3
verses.text: First, then, they make this objection to us, saying, that they ought not to believe on account of the discord of the sects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:4
verses.text: For the truth is warped when some teach one set of dogmas, others another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:5
verses.text: To whom we say, that among you who are Jews, and among the most famous of the philosophers among the Greeks, very many sects have sprung up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:6
verses.text: And yet you do not say that one ought to hesitate to philosophize or Judaize, because of the want of agreement of the sects among you between themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:7
verses.text: And then, that heresies should be sown among the truth, as "tares among the wheat," was foretold by the Lord; and what was predicted to take place could not but happen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:8
verses.text: And the cause of this is, that everything that is fair is followed by a foul blot.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:9
verses.text: If one, then, violate his engagements, and go aside from the confession which he makes before us, are we not to stick to the truth because he has belied his profession? But as the good man must not prove false or fail to ratify what he has promised, although others violate their engagements; so also are we bound in no way to transgress the canon of the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:10
verses.text: And especially do we keep our profession in the most important points, while they traverse it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:11
verses.text: Those, then, are to be believed, who hold firmly to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:12
verses.text: And we may broadly make use of this reply, and say to them, that physicians holding opposite opinions according to their own schools, yet equally in point of fact treat patients.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:13
verses.text: Does one, then, who is ill in body and needing treatment, not have recourse to a physician, on account of the different schools in medicine? No more, then, may he who in soul is sick and full of idols, make a pretext of the heresies, in reference to the recovery of health and conversion to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:14
verses.text: Further, it is said that it is on account of "those that are approved that heresies exist".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:15
verses.text: The apostle calls "approved," either those who in reaching faith apply to the teaching of the Lord with some discrimination (as those are called skilful money-changers, who distinguish the spurious coin from the genuine by the false  stamp), or those who have already become approved both in life and knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:16
verses.text: For this reason, then, we require greater attention and consideration in order to investigate how precisely we ought to live, and what is the true piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:17
verses.text: For it is plain that, from the very reason that truth is difficult and arduous of attainment, questions arise from which spring the heresies, savouring of self-love and vanity, of those who have not learned or apprehended truly, but only caught up a mere conceit of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:18
verses.text: With the greater care, therefore, are we to examine the real truth, which alone has for its object the true God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:19
verses.text: And the toil is followed by sweet discovery and reminiscence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:20
verses.text: On account of the heresies, therefore, the toil of discovery must be undertaken; but we must not at all abandon the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:21
verses.text: For, on fruit being set before us, some real and ripe, and some made of wax, as like the real as possible, we are not to abstain from both on account of the resemblance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:22
verses.text: But by the exercise of the apprehension of contemplation, and by reasoning of the most decisive character, we must distinguish the true from the seeming.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:23
verses.text: And as, while there is one royal highway, there are many others, some leading to a precipice, some to a rushing river or to a deep sea, no one will shrink from travelling by reason of the diversity, but will make use of the safe, and royal, and frequented way; so, though some say this, some that, concerning the truth, we must not abandon it; but must seek out the most accurate knowledge respecting it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:24
verses.text: Since also among garden-grown vegetables weeds also spring up, are the husbandmen, then, to desist from gardening?  Having then from nature abundant means for examining the statements made, we ought to discover the sequence of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:25
verses.text: Wherefore also we are rightly condemned, if we do not assent to what we ought to obey, and do not distinguish what is hostile, and unseemly, and unnatural, and false, from what is true, consistent, and seemly, and according to nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:26
verses.text: And these means must be employed in order to attain to the knowledge of the real truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:27
verses.text: This pretext is then, in the case of the Greeks, futile; for those who are willing may find the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:28
verses.text: But in the case of those who adduce unreasonable excuses, their condemnation is unanswerable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:29
verses.text: For whether do they deny or admit that there is such a thing as demonstration? I am of opinion that all will make the admission, except those who take away the senses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:30
verses.text: There being demonstration, then, it is necessary to condescend to questions, and to ascertain by way of demonstration by the Scriptures themselves how the heresies failed, and how in the truth alone and in the ancient Church is both the exactest knowledge, and the truly best set of principles (αἴρεσις).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:31
verses.text: Now, of those who diverge from the truth, some attempt to deceive themselves alone, and some also their neighbours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:32
verses.text: Those, then, who are called (δοξόσοφοι) wise in their own opinions, who think that they have found the truth, but have no true demonstration, deceive themselves in thinking that they have reached a resting place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:33
verses.text: And of whom there is no inconsiderable multitude, who avoid investigations for fear of refutations, and shun instructions for fear of condemnation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:34
verses.text: But those who deceive those who seek access to them are very astute; who, aware that they know nothing, yet darken the truth with plausible arguments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:35
verses.text: But, in my opinion, the nature of plausible arguments is of one character, and that of true arguments of another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 15:36
verses.text: And we know that it is necessary that the appellation of the heresies should be expressed in contradistinction to the truth; from which the Sophists, drawing certain things for the destruction of men, and burying them in human arts invented by themselves, glory rather in being at the head of a School than presiding over the Church.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 16—Scripture the Criterion by Which Truth and Heresy are Distinguished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:2
verses.text: But those who are ready to toil in the most excellent pursuits, will not desist from the search after truth, till they get the demonstration from the Scriptures themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:3
verses.text: There are certain criteria common to men, as the senses; and others that belong to those who have employed their wills and energies in what is true,—the methods which are pursued by the mind and reason, to distinguish between true and false propositions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:4
verses.text: Now, it is a very great thing to abandon opinion, by taking one's stand between accurate knowledge and the rash wisdom of opinion, and to know that he who hopes for everlasting rest knows also that the entrance to it is toilsome "and strait".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:5
verses.text: And let him who has once received the Gospel, even in the very hour in which he has come to the knowledge of salvation, "not turn back, like Lot's wife," as is said; and let him not go back either to his former life, which adheres to the things of sense, or to heresies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:6
verses.text: For they form the character, not knowing the true God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:7
verses.text: "For he that loveth father or mother more than Me," the Father and Teacher of the truth, who regenerates and creates anew, and  nourishes the elect soul, "is not worthy of Me"—He means, to be a son of God and a disciple of God, and at the same time also to be a friend, and of kindred nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:8
verses.text: "For no man who looks back, and puts his hand to the plough, is fit for the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:9
verses.text: But, as appears, many even down to our own time regard Mary, on account of the birth of her child, as having been in the puerperal state, although she was not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:10
verses.text: For some say that, after she brought forth, she was found, when examined, to be a virgin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:11
verses.text: Now such to us are the Scriptures of the Lord, which gave birth to the truth and continue virgin, in the concealment of the mysteries of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:12
verses.text: "And she brought forth, and yet brought not forth," says the Scripture; as having conceived of herself, and not from conjunction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:13
verses.text: Wherefore the Scriptures have conceived to Gnostics; but the heresies, not having learned them, dismissed them as not having conceived.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:14
verses.text: Now all men, having the same judgment, some, following the Word speaking, frame for themselves proofs; while others, giving themselves up to pleasures, wrest Scripture, in accordance with their lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:15
verses.text: And the lover of truth, as I think, needs force of soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:16
verses.text: For those who make the greatest attempts must fail in things of the highest importance; unless, receiving from the truth itself the rule of the truth, they cleave to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:17
verses.text: But such people, in consequence of falling away from the right path, err in most individual points; as you might expect from not having the faculty for judging of what is true and false, strictly trained to select what is essential.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:18
verses.text: For if they had, they would have obeyed the Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:19
verses.text: As, then, if a man should, similarly to those drugged by Circe, become a beast; so he, who has spurned the ecclesiastical tradition, and darted off to the opinions of heretical men, has ceased to be a man of God and to remain faithful to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:20
verses.text: But he who has returned from this deception, on hearing the Scriptures, and turned his life to the truth, is, as it were, from being a man made a god.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:21
verses.text: For we have, as the source of teaching, the Lord, both by the prophets, the Gospel, and the blessed apostles, "in divers manners and at sundry times," leading from the beginning of knowledge to the end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:22
verses.text: But if one should suppose that another origin was required, then no longer truly could an origin be preserved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:23
verses.text: He, then, who of himself believes the Scripture and voice of the Lord, which by the Lord acts to the benefiting of men, is rightly regarded faithful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:24
verses.text: Certainly we use it as a criterion in the discovery of things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:25
verses.text: What is subjected to criticism is not believed till it is so subjected; so that what needs criticism cannot be a first principle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:26
verses.text: Therefore, as is reasonable, grasping by faith the indemonstrable first principle, and receiving in abundance, from the first principle itself, demonstrations in reference to the first principle, we are by the voice of the Lord trained up to the knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:27
verses.text: For we may not give our adhesion to men on a bare statement by them, who might equally state the opposite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:28
verses.text: But if it is not enough merely to state the opinion, but if what is stated must be confirmed, we do not wait for the testimony of men, but we establish the matter that is in question by the voice of the Lord, which is the surest of all demonstrations, or rather is the only demonstration; in which knowledge those who have merely tasted the Scriptures are believers; while those who, having advanced further, and become correct expounders of the truth, are Gnostics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:29
verses.text: Since also, in what pertains to life, craftsmen are superior to ordinary people, and model what is beyond common notions; so, consequently, we also, giving a complete exhibition of the Scriptures from the Scriptures themselves, from faith persuade by demonstration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:30
verses.text: And if those also who follow heresies venture to avail themselves of the prophetic Scriptures; in the first place they will not make use of all the Scriptures, and then they will not quote them entire, nor as the body and texture of prophecy prescribe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:31
verses.text: But, selecting ambiguous expressions, they wrest them to their own opinions, gathering a few expressions here and there; not looking to the sense, but making use of the mere words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:32
verses.text: For in almost all the quotations they make, you will find that they attend to the names alone, while they alter the meanings; neither knowing, as they affirm, nor using the quotations they adduce, according to their true nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:33
verses.text: But the truth is not found by changing the meanings (for so people subvert all true teaching), but in the consideration of what perfectly belongs to and becomes the Sovereign God, and in establishing each one of the points demonstrated in the Scriptures again from similar Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:34
verses.text: Neither, then, do they want to turn to the  truth, being ashamed to abandon the claims of self-love; nor are they able to manage their opinions, by doing violence to the Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:35
verses.text: But having first promulgated false dogmas to men; plainly fighting against almost the whole Scriptures, and constantly confuted by us who contradict them; for the rest, even now partly they hold out against admitting the prophetic Scriptures, and partly disparage us as of a different nature, and incapable of understanding what is peculiar to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:36
verses.text: And sometimes even they deny their own dogmas, when these are confuted, being ashamed openly to own what in private they glory in teaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:37
verses.text: For this may be seen in all the heresies, when you examine the iniquities of their dogmas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:38
verses.text: For when they are overturned by our clearly showing that they are opposed to the Scriptures, one of two things may be seen to have been done by those who defend the dogma.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:39
verses.text: For they either despise the consistency of their own dogmas, or despise the prophecy itself, or rather their own hope.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:40
verses.text: And they invariably prefer what seems to them to be more evident to what has been spoken by the Lord through the prophets and by the Gospel, and, besides, attested and confirmed by the apostles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:41
verses.text: Seeing, therefore, the danger that they are in (not in respect of one dogma, but in reference to the maintenance of the heresies) of not discovering the truth; for while reading the books we have ready at hand, they despise them as useless, but in their eagerness to surpass common faith, they have diverged from the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:42
verses.text: For, in consequence of not learning the mysteries of ecclesiastical knowledge, and not having capacity for the grandeur of the truth, too indolent to descend to the bottom of things, reading superficially, they have dismissed the Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:43
verses.text: Elated, then, by vain opinion, they are incessantly wrangling, and plainly care more to seem than to be philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:44
verses.text: Not laying as foundations the necessary first principles of things; and influenced by human opinions, then making the end to suit them, by compulsion; on account of being confuted, they spar with those who are engaged in the prosecution of the true philosophy, and undergo everything, and, as they say, ply every oar, even going the length of impiety, by disbelieving the Scriptures, rather than be removed from the honours of the heresy and the boasted first seat in their churches; on account of which also they eagerly embrace that convivial couch of honour in the Agape, falsely so called.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:45
verses.text: The knowledge of the truth among us from what is already believed, produces faith in what is not yet believed; which faith is, so to speak, the essence of demonstration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:46
verses.text: But, as appears, no heresy has at all ears to hear what is useful, but opened only to what leads to pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:47
verses.text: Since also, if one of them would only obey the truth, he would be healed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:48
verses.text: Now the cure of self-conceit (as of every ailment) is threefold: the ascertaining of the cause, and the mode of its removal; and thirdly, the training of the soul, and the accustoming it to assume a right attitude to the judgments come to.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:49
verses.text: For, just like a disordered eye, so also the soul that has been darkened by unnatural dogmas cannot perceive distinctly the light of truth, but even overlooks what is before it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:50
verses.text: They say, then, that in muddy water eels are caught by being blinded.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:51
verses.text: And just as knavish boys bar out the teacher, so do these shut out the prophecies from their Church, regarding them with suspicion by reason of rebuke and admonition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:52
verses.text: In fact, they stitch together a multitude of lies and figments, that they may appear acting in accordance with reason in not admitting the Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:53
verses.text: So, then, they are not pious, inasmuch as they are not pleased with the divine commands, that is, with the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:54
verses.text: And as those almonds are called empty in which the contents are worthless, not those in which there is nothing; so also we call those heretics empty, who are destitute of the counsels of God and the traditions of Christ; bitter, in truth, like the wild almond, their dogmas originating with themselves, with the exception of such truths as they could not, by reason of their evidence, discard and conceal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:55
verses.text: As, then, in war the soldier must not leave the post which the commander has assigned him, so neither must we desert the post assigned by the Word, whom we have received as the guide of knowledge and of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:56
verses.text: But the most have not even inquired, if there is one that we ought to follow, and who this is, and how he is to be followed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:57
verses.text: For as is the Word, such also must the believer's life be, so as to be able to follow God, who brings all things to end from the beginning by the right course.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:58
verses.text: But when one has transgressed against the Word, and thereby against God; if it is through becoming powerless in consequence of some impression being suddenly made, he ought to see to have the impressions of reasons at hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:59
verses.text: And if it is that he has become "common," as the Scripture says, in consequence of being overcome the habits which formerly had sway by over him, the habits must be entirely put a stop to, and the soul trained to oppose them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:60
verses.text: And if it appears that conflicting dogmas draw some away, these must be taken out of the way,  and recourse is to be had to those who reconcile dogmas, and subdue by the charm of the Scriptures such of the untutored as are timid, by explaining the truth by the connection of the Testaments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:61
verses.text: But, as appears, we incline to ideas founded on opinion, though they be contrary, rather than to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:62
verses.text: For it is austere and grave.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:63
verses.text: Now, since there are three states of the soul—ignorance, opinion, knowledge—those who are in ignorance are the Gentiles, those in knowledge, the true Church, and those in opinion, the Heretics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:64
verses.text: Nothing, then, can be more clearly seen than those, who know, making affirmations about what they know, and the others respecting what they hold on the strength of opinion, as far as respects affirmation without proof.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:65
verses.text: They accordingly despise and laugh at one another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:66
verses.text: And it happens that the same thought is held in the highest estimation by some, and by others condemned for insanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:67
verses.text: And, indeed, we have learned that voluptuousness, which is to be attributed to the Gentiles, is one thing; and wrangling, which is preferred among the heretical sects, is another; and joy, which is to be appropriated to the Church, another; and delight, which is to be assigned to the true Gnostic, another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:68
verses.text: And as, if one devote himself to Ischomachus, he will make him a farmer; and to Lampis, a mariner; and to Charidemus, a military commander; and to Simon, an equestrian; and to Perdices, a trader; and to Crobylus, a cook; and to Archelaus, a dancer; and to Homer, a poet; and to Pyrrho, a wrangler; and to Demosthenes, an orator; and to Chrysippus, a dialectician; and to Aristotle, a naturalist; and to Plato, a philosopher: so he who listens to the Lord, and follows the prophecy given by Him, will be formed perfectly in the likeness of the teacher—made a god going about in flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:69
verses.text: Accordingly, those fall from this eminence who follow not God whither He leads.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:70
verses.text: And He leads us in the inspired Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:71
verses.text: Though men's actions are ten thousand in number, the sources of all sin are but two, ignorance and inability.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:72
verses.text: And both depend on ourselves; inasmuch as we will not learn, nor, on the other hand, restrain lust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:73
verses.text: And of these, the one is that, in consequence of which people do not judge well, and the other that, in consequence of which they cannot comply with right judgments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:74
verses.text: For neither will one who is deluded in his mind be able to act rightly, though perfectly able to do what he knows; nor, though capable of judging what is requisite, will he keep himself free of blame, if destitute of power in action.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:75
verses.text: Consequently, then, there are assigned two kinds of correction applicable to both kinds of sin: for the one, knowledge and clear demonstration from the testimony of the Scriptures; and for the other, the training according to the Word, which is regulated by the discipline of faith and fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:76
verses.text: And both develop into perfect love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:77
verses.text: For the end of the Gnostic here is, in my judgment, twofold,—partly scientific contemplation, partly action.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:78
verses.text: Would, then, that these heretics would learn and be set right by these notes, and turn to the sovereign God! But if, like the deaf serpents, they listen not to the song called new, though very old, may they be chastised by God, and undergo paternal admonitions previous to the Judgment, till they become ashamed and repent, but not rush through headlong unbelief, and precipitate themselves into judgment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:79
verses.text: For there are partial corrections, which are called chastisements, which many of us who have been in transgression incur, by falling away from the Lord's people.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:80
verses.text: But as children are chastised by their teacher, or their father, so are we by Providence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:81
verses.text: But God does not punish, for punishment is retaliation for evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:82
verses.text: He chastises, however, for good to those who are chastised, collectively and individually.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:83
verses.text: I have adduced these things from a wish to avert those, who are eager to learn, from the liability to fall into heresies, and out of a desire to stop them from superficial ignorance, or stupidity, or bad disposition, or whatever it should be called.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:84
verses.text: And in the attempt to persuade and lead to the truth those who are not entirely incurable, I have made use of these words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:85
verses.text: For there are some who cannot bear at all to listen to those who exhort them to turn to the truth; and they attempt to trifle, pouring out blasphemies against the truth, claiming for themselves the knowledge of the greatest things in the universe, without having learned, or inquired, or laboured, or discovered the consecutive train of ideas,—whom one should pity rather than hate for such perversity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:86
verses.text: But if one is curable, able to bear (like fire or steel) the outspokenness of the truth, which cuts away and burns their false opinions, let him lend the ears of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:87
verses.text: And this will be the case, unless, through the propensity to sloth, they push truth away, or through the desire of fame, endeavour to invent novelties.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:88
verses.text: For those are slothful who, having it in their power to provide themselves with proper proofs for the divine Scriptures from the Scriptures themselves, select only what contributes to their own pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:89
verses.text: And those have a craving for glory who voluntarily evade, by arguments of a diverse sort, the things delivered by the blessed apostles and teachers, which are wedded to inspired words; opposing the divine tradition by human teachings,  in order to establish the heresy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:90
verses.text: For, in truth, what remained to be said—in ecclesiastical knowledge I mean—by such men, Marcion, for example, or Prodicus, and such like, who did not walk in the right way? For they could not have surpassed their predecessors in wisdom, so as to discover anything in addition to what had been uttered by them; for they would have been satisfied had they been able to learn the things laid down before.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:91
verses.text: Our Gnostic then alone, having grown old in the Scriptures, and maintaining apostolic and ecclesiastic orthodoxy in doctrines, lives most correctly in accordance with the Gospel, and discovers the proofs, for which he may have made search (sent forth as he is by the Lord), from the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:92
verses.text: For the life of the Gnostic, in my view, is nothing but deeds and words corresponding to the tradition of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:93
verses.text: But "all have not knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:94
verses.text: For I would not have you to be ignorant, brethren," says the apostle, "that all were under the cloud, and partook of spiritual meat and drink;" clearly affirming that all who heard the word did not take in the magnitude of knowledge in deed and word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:95
verses.text: Wherefore also he added: "But with all of them He was not well pleased".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:96
verses.text: Who is this? He who said, "Why do you call Me Lord, and do not the will of My Father?" That is the Saviour's teaching, which to us is spiritual food, and drink that knows no thirst, the water of gnostic life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:97
verses.text: Further it is said, knowledge is said "to puff up".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:98
verses.text: To whom we say: Perchance seeming knowledge is said to puff up, if one suppose the expression means "to be swollen up".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:99
verses.text: But if, as is rather the case, the expression of the apostle means, "to entertain great and true sentiments," the difficulty is solved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:100
verses.text: Following, then, the Scriptures, let us establish what has been said: "Wisdom," says Solomon, "has inflated her children".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:101
verses.text: For the Lord did not work conceit by the particulars of His teaching; but He produces trust in the truth and expansion of mind, in the knowledge that is communicated by the Scriptures, and contempt for the things which drag into sin, which is the meaning of the expression "inflated".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:102
verses.text: It teaches the magnificence of the wisdom implanted in her children by instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:103
verses.text: Now the apostle says, "I will know not the speech of those that are puffed up, but the power;" if ye understand the Scriptures magnanimously (which means truly; for nothing is greater than truth).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:104
verses.text: For in that lies the power of the children of wisdom who are puffed up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:105
verses.text: He says, as it were, I shall know if ye rightly entertain great thoughts respecting knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:106
verses.text: "For God," according to David, "is known in Judea," that is, those that are Israelites according to knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:107
verses.text: For Judea is interpreted "Confession".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:108
verses.text: It is, then, rightly said by the apostle, "This Thou, shall not commit adultery, Thou shall not steal, Thou shalt not covet; and if there be any other commandment, it is comprehended in this word, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:109
verses.text: For we must never, as do those who follow the heresies, adulterate the truth, or steal the canon of the Church, by gratifying our own lusts and vanity, by defrauding our neighbours; whom above all it is our duty, in the exercise of love to them, to teach to adhere to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:110
verses.text: It is accordingly expressly said, "Declare among the heathen His statutes," that they may not be judged, but that those who have previously given ear may be converted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 16:111
verses.text: But those who speak treacherously with their tongues have the penalties that are on record.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17—The Tradition of the Church Prior to that of the Heresies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:2
verses.text: Those, then, that adhere to impious words, and dictate them to others, inasmuch as they do not make a right but a perverse use of the divine words, neither themselves enter into the kingdom of heaven, nor permit those whom they have deluded to attain the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:3
verses.text: But not having the key of entrance, but a false (and as the common phrase expresses it), a counterfeit key (ἀντικλεῖς), by which they do not enter in as we enter in, through the tradition of the Lord, by drawing aside the curtain; but bursting through the side-door, and digging clandestinely through the wall of the Church, and stepping over the truth, they constitute themselves the Mystagogues of the soul of the impious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:4
verses.text: For that the human assemblies which they held were posterior to the Catholic Church requires not many words to show.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:5
verses.text: For the teaching of our Lord at His advent, beginning with Augustus and Tiberius, was completed in the middle of the times of Tiberius.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:6
verses.text: And that of the apostles, embracing the ministry of Paul, ends with Nero.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:7
verses.text: It was later, in the times of Adrian the king, that those who invented the heresies arose; and they extended to the age of Antoninus the elder, as, for instance, Basilides, though he claims (as they boast) for his master, Glaucias, the interpreter of Peter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:8
verses.text: Likewise they allege that Valentinus was a hearer of Theudas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:9
verses.text: And he was the pupil of Paul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:10
verses.text: For Marcion, who arose in the same age with them, lived as an old man with the younger heretics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:11
verses.text: And after him Simon heard for a little the preaching of Peter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:12
verses.text: Such being the case, it is evident, from the high antiquity and perfect truth of the Church, that these later heresies, and those yet subsequent to them in time, were new inventions falsified from the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:13
verses.text: From what has been said, then, it is my opinion that the true Church, that which is really ancient, is one, and that in it those who according to God's purpose are just, are enrolled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:14
verses.text: For from the very reason that God is one, and the Lord one, that which is in the highest degree honourable is lauded in consequence of its singleness, being an imitation of the one first principle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:15
verses.text: In the nature of the One, then, is associated in a joint heritage the one Church, which they strive to cut asunder into many sects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:16
verses.text: Therefore in substance and idea, in origin, in pre-eminence, we say that the ancient and Catholic Church is alone, collecting as it does into the unity of the one faith—which results from the peculiar Testaments, or rather the one Testament in different times by the will of the one God, through one Lord—those already ordained, whom God predestinated, knowing before the foundation of the world that they would be righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:17
verses.text: But the pre-eminence of the Church, as the principle of union, is, in its oneness, in this surpassing all things else, and having nothing like or equal to itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:18
verses.text: But of this afterwards.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:19
verses.text: Of the heresies, some receive their appellation from a person's name, as that which is called after Valentinus, and that after Marcion, and that after Basilides, although they boast of adducing the opinion of Matthew without truth; for as the teaching, so also the tradition of the apostles was one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 17:20
verses.text: Some take their designation from a place, as the Peratici; some from a nation, as the heresy of the Phrygians; some from an action, as that of the Encratites; and some from peculiar dogmas, as that of the Docetae, and that of the Haermatites; and some from suppositions, and from individuals they have honoured, as those called Cainists, and the Ophians; and some from nefarious practices and enormities, as those of the Simonians called Entychites.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII—The Distinction Between Clean and Unclean Animals in the Law Symbolical of the Distinction Between the Church, and Jews, and Heretics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:2
verses.text: After showing a little peep-hole to those who love to contemplate the Church from the law of sacrifices respecting clean and unclean animals (inasmuch as thus the common Jews and the heretics are distinguished mystically from the divine Church), let us bring the discourse to a close.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:3
verses.text: For such of the sacrifices as part the hoof, and ruminate, the Scripture represents as clean and acceptable to God; since the just obtain access to the Father and to the Son by faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:4
verses.text: For this is the stability of those who part the hoof, those who study the oracles of God night and day, and ruminate them in the soul's receptacle for instructions; which gnostic exercise the Law expresses under the figure of the rumination of the clean animal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:5
verses.text: But such as have neither the one nor the other of those qualities it separates as unclean.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:6
verses.text: Now those that ruminate, but do not part the hoof, indicate the majority of the Jews, who have indeed the oracles of God, but have not faith, and the step which, resting on the truth, conveys to the Father by the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:7
verses.text: Whence also this kind of cattle are apt to slip, not having a division in the foot, and not resting on the twofold support of faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:8
verses.text: For "no man," it is said, "knoweth the Father, but he to whom the Son shall reveal Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:9
verses.text: And again, those also are likewise unclean that part the hoof, but do not ruminate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:10
verses.text: For these point out the heretics, who indeed go upon the name of the Father and the Son, but are incapable  of triturating and grinding down the clear declaration of the oracles, and who, besides, perform the works of righteousness coarsely and not with precision, if they perform them at all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:11
verses.text: To such the Lord says, "Why will ye call me Lord, Lord, and do not the things which I say?"  And those that neither part the hoof nor chew the cud are entirely unclean.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:12
verses.text: "But ye Megareans," says Theognis, "are neither third, nor fourth, Nor twelfth, neither in reckoning nor in number,"  "but as chaff which the wind drives away from the face of the earth," and as a drop from a vessel".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:13
verses.text: These points, then, having been formerly thoroughly treated, and the department of ethics having been sketched summarily in a fragmentary way, as we promised; and having here and there interspersed the dogmas which are the germs of true knowledge, so that the discovery of the sacred traditions may not be easy to any one of the uninitiated, let us proceed to what we promised.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:14
