verses.text: Now the Miscellanies are not like parts laid out, planted in regular order for the delight of the eye, but rather like an umbrageous and shaggy hill, planted with laurel, and ivy, and apples, and olives, and figs; the planting being purposely a mixture of fruit-bearing and fruitless trees, since the composition aims at concealment, on account of those that have the daring to pilfer and steal the ripe fruits; from which, however, the husbandmen, transplanting shoots and plants, will adorn a beautiful park and a delightful grove.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:15
verses.text: The Miscellanies, then, study neither arrangement nor diction; since there are even cases in which the Greeks on purpose wish that ornate diction should be absent, and imperceptibly cast in the seed of dogmas, not according to the truth, rendering such as may read laborious and quick at discovery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:16
verses.text: For many and various are the baits for the various kinds of fishes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:17
verses.text: And now, after this seventh Miscellany of ours, we shall give the account of what follows in order from another commencement.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:18
verses.text: Elucidations  I.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:19
verses.text: (Deception, cap.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:20
verses.text: 9 - p)  More and more, the casuistry exposed by Pascal in the Provincial Letters becomes an important subject for the investigation of Americans.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:21
verses.text: Nobody who has any pretensions to scholarship can afford to be ignorant of these letters; for they belong to literature, and not merely to theology.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:22
verses.text: But they belong in a sense to the past; not that "the Society of Jesus" has ceased to maintain all that Pascal has exposed, and to practice even worse, but that the Latin churches have, since the days of Pascal, been formally subjected to a system of casuistry, in some respects superficially reformed, but in all other respects radically bad, and corrosive to society.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:23
verses.text: In Pascal's day this casuistry could only be charged upon individuals, and upon societies and communities: the Roman Church everywhere adopted it, but was not formally committed to it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:24
verses.text: But in the system of Liguori this corrupt morality has been made authoritative and dogmatic; so that in all the Latin churches it becomes the base of the confessional.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:25
verses.text: For moral purposes, it is the Bible of the millions who resort to their confessors and "directors".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:26
verses.text: These remarks, however, are here introduced merely with reference to the morals of Clement with regard to truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:27
verses.text: I have briefly indicated, in the footnotes, the points which are to be noted in forming an opinion of our author's conceptions of this vital principle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:28
verses.text: They seem to me conformed to the Gospel; to the teachings of Him who allows no hair-splittings, but says, "Let your yea be yea,  and your nay, nay".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:29
verses.text: But, as the text stood in the Edinburgh translation, it did injustice to Clement in one passage, which I have modified.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:30
verses.text: It reads, "He (the Gnostic) both thinks and speaks the truth, unless, at any time, medicinally, as a physician for the safety of the sick, he may lie, or tell an untruth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:31
verses.text: To this, Clement adds significantly, "according to the Sophists".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:32
verses.text: That is to say, our author tolerates the Christian who has not got beyond the Sophists with respect to benevolent deceptions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:33
verses.text: As killing is not always murder, so some, even among stern moralists, have maintained that deception by word of mouth is not always lying.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:34
verses.text: This is the extent to which Clement tolerates sophistry, and he goes on to demand the practice of truth in Gospel terms.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:35
verses.text: Now, thank God, the English word "lie" is always infamous; and there is nothing like it, in this respect, in other languages.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:36
verses.text: The Sophists themselves did not so understand the Greek word (ψεῦδος), when they apply it to the benevolent deception of a physician, or to the untruths used benevolently with the insane.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:37
verses.text: Nothing infamous attaches to the French word mensonge when used for what are deemed "innocent deceptions".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:38
verses.text: With this whole system of sophistry I have no patience at all; but, in justice to the Sophists, let us not make them worse than they were.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:39
verses.text: They did not understand that such deceptions were lies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:40
verses.text: Hence, for "lie," I have used the word deceive, correcting a needless rendering of the text, and one to which Clement should not be made to extend even a contemptuous toleration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:41

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:61
verses.text: )  The Primitive Fathers never dream of anything as dogma which cannot be proved by the Scriptures, save only that the apostolic traditions, clearly proved to be such, must be referred to in proving what is Holy Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:62
verses.text: It is not possible to graft on this principle the slightest argument for any tradition not indisputably apostolic, so far as the de fide is concerned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:63
verses.text: Quod semper is the touchstone, in their conceptions, of all orthodoxy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VII 18:64
verses.text: No matter who may teach this or that, now or in any post-apostolic age, their test is Holy Scripture, and the inquiry, Was it always so taught and understood?.
